editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE MALL: OR THE Modish Lovers. A COMEDY. Acted by His Majesties Servants.
LONDON, Printed for William Cademan, at the Popes-head in the lower Walk of the New Exchange in the Strand. 1674.

div.head: TO WILLIAM WHITCOMB, Iunior, Esq
div.p:
I Need not plead the priviledge, which the Tribe of Scriblers may lay claim too in Dedications, since your favours excuse these weak respects I pay you in a publick acknowledgement. All the interest I have in the Play, is inferiour to the Glory I take, in seeing your Name fixt in the Frontispiece; which methinks, gives it a resemblance to the Structure of Minda, where the Porch far exceeds the House. I know you have a Victorious Soul, and thence I do my self the Honour (not without policy too, especially in the time of threatning Thunder, when Demicracks of the Town, according to custome, will bark at Shadows) to run under your Laurel, to avoid the Clap. Many there are yet to unload their Mouth Granadoes, those especially whose own actions were advise to the Painterâ–ª
yet for any Gentleman to become an infected mock Critick for Fashion sake, is as much beneath his credit as to wear a Velvet Coat, when every Iohn-a-Nokes presumes the fashion. I am very much in pain for the violence done to my inclin â€¢ tion, whereby I am forbid to acknowledge the Person, and Obligations done to the Play, only (as 'tis said) in favour to my interest. What e're the reason be, I think the Play highly advanc'd in lying at your Feet; But in the mean while I pray, 'twere in my pow'r to present you with something Heroick, and like your self. I am proud ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ you want no Soul, but Titles to ã€ˆâ€¦ã€‰ popular, and wishing you the measure of your Worth, I think it duty to subscribe my self, the
div.closer:
Humblest of all your Creatures, I. D.
Poetis nulla Potestas.

div.head: The Prologue.
div.l: WHen you cry Poets down, and damn 'um thus,
Like Vipers slain, they grow more numerous:
Like to Aegypt's Plagues around you swarm,
But you are proof against such common charm:
We know that none, beside a first rate Wit,
Can please the grand Inhabiters o'th Pit;
While others work's, each Ninny of the Town,
Takes priviledge to damn for half a Crown.
Our Muse wants complaisance, knows not the Court,
Although she fain wou'd be a prostitute;
Her walks are very near, and there you'l find,
Her Evening love, too soft to be unkind:
Yet those that Criticks are, for fashion sake
Will judge this dull, which scarce is a mistake;
And finding one fault, will make ten times more,
Oft force a flaw where there was none before.
Yet if your bisses poyson, this he sues
You wou'd some lingring, painful sentence choose.
Prove Tyrants, and with leisure till the third day, kill.
Thunder Damnation then, and what you will.

Courtwell

list.label: Lovechange.

list.item: A foolish Country Knight, Rival to Amorous.

list.item: Servant to Grace, and Nephew to Mr's Woodbee.

Mrs. Woodbee.

list.item: In love with Amorous, and Ne â€¢â€¢â€¢ to old Easy.

div.p: Scene St. Iames's Park, with the adjacent Places.

div.head: THE MALL: OR THE Modish Lovers.
Actus Primus,
Scena Prima.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: A Pox of this Love, how damn'd and Idle t'has made me, here have I march'd a long half hour, which Egad is an Age to me, to wait for this Ambassadour of my amorous Negotiation, pray Heaven no Rival of mine leads her into Temptation!

Oh Lady!
Enter Peg.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: O Lord! What make you here so early?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Oh Peg, thou know'st Love is a restless Bedfellow, Peg, alas, who could sleep, that could but hope the blessing of seeing thy sweet Mistress. Peg, Well, what news, what news, from Cupids Court Wench, ha! Will she be kind, and consider my Passion, faith I am but a dead Man without a little comfort.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Faith Sir, I am not idle in your behalf, I take all opportunities (which is) when her Husband's out of the way, to let her know my thoughts of you, which Ile assure you Sir are most advantagious.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I am beholding to thee Peg.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: But you know Sir, she's a married Woman, and ought to be very cautious.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Oh Peg, I love her with a vertuous Flame, believe me I do! and if thou wouldst but swear and lye, and use a small kind of Treachery in the Case â€”

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: You need not doubt such small services Sir â€” Butâ€”

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: But thou must be a little encouraged, is it so? Here, here's a pair of Angels to invite thee to speak.â€” gives her Money.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Do you take me for Balaams Ass Sir, that can't speak without a Prompter, however Sir, you court me in no common Language.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Oh thou art a Saint, that will despise a Prayer, made in the vulgar Tongue, here Proxy, here's my Hand, and Seal, get it deliver'd, and further the design.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I, but Sir, is there no harm in't?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: What dost thou call harm?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I mean Sir, is there nothing, but what I may carry with Honour?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Fye, fye Peg, dost think I'de make a Bawd of thee?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I hope you wou'd not at my years.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Right, having so many yet to come of the kind and amorous ones, But this Letter Peg is only to invite thy Mistress into the Park to night. I know the Evening will be fair, and if she can make an escape from that old impotent Letcher her Husband, I shall be glad to kiss her hands there.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Is this all?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Upon my Life.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Then rest in hope, for I dare promise ye.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Farewel dear Peg.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p:
Your Servant sweet Mr. Lovechange.
Exit Peg.

div.stage: Enter Courtwell who meets Lovechange going out.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Lovechange, I have been a dozen times at thy Lodging to see thee, but, like the Devil, thou art always ranging about, seeking whom thou canst devour.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p:
Thou hast small reason to accuse me Courtwell, for since thy arrival from Spain I have not enjoy'd thee at our old rate; we were wont to Whose, and drink together like loving Brothers in Iniquity, but I think thou now hast taken up a little of the Formality of
the Climate, and dost all thy Debaucheries in secret.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: No Ned, I have rather learnt the sobriety of that Nation, and have left off those lewd courses.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Nay, if thou bee'st come to that, to call e'm lewd thoud'st better e'n have staid amongst e'm, for thou art unfit for this Town Egad Will.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I think I had not so soon abandon'd that agreeable place, but for the Commands of my Uncle Easy, upon whom my Fortune does so depend, that I dare not disobey him in any thing.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: What, Ile warrant ye, he has that old fashion'd design of Matrimony in his head, he means to marry thee.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Some such thing.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: And who is the wretched thing, I pray?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: The rich Widdow Wou'dbee, she's damn'd ill-favour'd, and they say as ill natur'd, but she'l serve for a Wife Ned.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: How, the Widdow Wou'dbeeâ€”my Wife Egad! aside

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Yes the very same.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Hark ye William, I don't like the match William!

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Your Reasons?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I have divers, and sundry â€” That must be nameless aside

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Let's hear a few of them.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Why, first she's Old, next Jealous, she is, to Damnation, Proud, Expensive, and â€”

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: This is all nothing.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: She is besideâ€” a Plague on him I dare not discoverâ€” aside

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: What Sir?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Nay, nay dear heart, no passion prithee, for she's very honest, which makes her very insolent.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Oh I am glad 'twas no worse.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Worse! Nay here's ill qualities enough for one Woman a Conscience â€” But prithee was there never a Dona in all Spain worthy your kindness, but you must come back to England, and like a Iew, be forc'd to Wed in your own Tribe, ha!

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Prithee don't call any Sins to remembrance, Oh Friend! I had a Mistress in Spain, and such a Mistress, so kind, so fairâ€”

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: And so tyr'd you out with loving, was't not so? Aye there's the Devil on't.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: No, in an unhappy Adventure wherein I took the party of an English Cavaleir my Friend, I kill'd her Brother, who was of Quality sufficient to cause me to fear the inquisition, so I was forc'd to quit Spain, and meeting with the Command of my Uncleâ€”

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: You soon lost the thoughts of your Mistress, and I shall advise you, as you love health and liberty! two excellent qualities, to loose the thoughts of this Widdow too.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Nay, since I cannot marry where I like, Ile e'n marry for a World of Money, that's the next way, and the nearest I know to happiness, therefore I am resolved to put on the Fetters.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Pox on't they'l gingle after thee at that rate that all pretty Ladies will shun thee for a fusty Husband, and who would be ty'd up from Ranging.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: There are Ladies Ned, who consider not the Man, but his Pockets, half a peece for a clean pair of Sheets, half a Crown for a thrice retayl'd Bottle of Rhenish, and â€”

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: The Pox into the bargain.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: The Pox in others will be but the Gout in me.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Your Uncle Sir, stays for you to go make a visit to the Widdow Woodbee.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Ile attend him.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: You ought to ask me leave first Sir, if you knew allâ€” Tis well I am not a jealous Husband, and 'tis better I have no tempting Wife. [aside] Well Sir you will go thenâ€”

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Without doubt.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Well Love speed you Sir, 'tis well you're young enough to spare some hours, for o'my Conscience tis meer loss of time.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Farewel, farewel Sir, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Let them laugh that win Sir, adieu.

div.head: Scene Second.

sp.speaker: Perig.
sp.l: For Mrs. Woodbee at her house in Reading the superscription of a Letter.
St. Iames's street,â€” London.â€”
Sure 'tis hereabout.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: This must be the house Ile knock till they answer. knocks
Is this the Lady Woodbee's, Sweetheart?

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: It is Sir, may I know your affairs with her, for she is a little busie at present.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I am a Stranger by Nation a Spaniard, and bring her Letters from her Brother who is Consul there.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Please you walk in Sir.â€” They go in and return.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Well Diego, thus far our business is prosperous, we are arriv'd to a Land, rich, and beautiful, and where the civility of the Inhabitants give me all the encouragement I can expect, grant ye gods I may find out this perfidious Renigado of Love, and Ile forgive what e're you make me suffer another way.
Madam, you I take it are the Lady to whom I am addrest, & these will inform you, why I take this freedom. Gives her Letters, she reads

sp.speaker: Woud.
sp.p: Sir, I am not only oblig'd by the Laws of good manners, and civility to receive you well as a Stranger, but the Character my Brother gives me of you, binds me to a more strict observance: Sir, you're welcome, believe so, and command my house.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Madam, you honour me, and if I take a freedom that unbecomes me, charge it on your bounty, not my boldness.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: A pretty youth introth Clare, is it not?

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Yes indeed Madam.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Madam, Ile take my leave for a few hours to see the City, which done Ile wait on you agen. kisses her hand.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: So, right Woman, can no more be without a Man, then a Puritan without his Bible.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p:
The Widdow looks very amorous upon him, methinks tis a fine Youth.
To Easy aside.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Mr. Easy, Sir your servant.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: No interruption, Lady, no interruption.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: None in the World Sir I protest, this is a Person of Worth and Merit, recommended to me by the only Brother I have, and for whose sake besides his own I am oblig'd to pay him my respects.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p:
By my faith, and he deserves it Lady, he is handsome, and young â€” But Lady, I have, once more, brought my Nephew to wait on you, and to know your resolution concerning those propositions I made you of Marriage, Ile make short work on't, I'me no Courtier, but let him speak for himself, he can talk many fine things of Love, and the like â€” In the mean time Ile take a turn in the Garden.
Exit Easy

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: gods! Is not that Courtwell? I must withdraw, or dye; in what a happy hour am I arriv'd, to be a witness of his injustice! Oh Fortune! thou hast recompenc'd me for all the injuries thou hast done me, [aside] Madam! your humble Servant, it shall not be many hours before I kiss your hands agen.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p:
They will seem many to me,
Exit Perigreen looking with scorn on Courtwell. believe me Gentle Sir.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I find Widdow, though you profess a great deal of cruelty, and coldness to me, you can be kind too, when you please.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I am sorry you should take me for an insensible Mr. Courtwell, though for many reasons I am forc'd to say I cannot admit of any concern for your self, in a Word Sir I have reasons (that must be secret ones) to tell you, I cannot entertain your passion, I am a Person Sir, that â€”

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Seems to have heat enough about you Widdow for half a score, faith view me well, I am a strait chin'd fellow, clean limb'd, and sweet, and dare promise as much as any Man.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: And perform as little as most Men; Well, just thus did my Husband promise before I had him, and now, though even in the Non age of our Marriage, nay before the Wedding Sheets were sufficiently tumbled, I find him as reasonable a quiet Soul, as heart can wish. aside

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: What i'st you consult on Widdow.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: In earnest Sir, I am past consideration, for I am resolv'd upon the matter.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Not to marry?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: By no means Sir, not you.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Why then the Devil take thee for making me loose so much of my pretious time, why thou Unmerciful, Insatiable Widdow, that art not only content, to let me miss of thee, but the opportunity of gaining at least a dozen hearts of perhaps handsomer Women then thy self Widdow.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: How Mr. Courtwell, handsomer! you are rude Sir, I must tell you.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Handsomer! Why thou didst not take thy self to be a Beauty sure! but yet thou hast charms Widdow in bank, which are alurements I confess, and 'twas well thou hadst 'em at these years.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Yearsâ€” Certainly I don't pass for a Sibel with you? this is beyond all patience, Clare, where's Mr. Easy?

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Taking a turn i'th Garden Madam.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Let him come and carry off his scurvy Nephew here, or I shall set my Footman to do it in a more undecent manner: years quoth a'!

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Fye on't, Age makes thee testy Widdow, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Oh intollerable Mr. Easy, do you bring your Kinsman to affront me?

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: How Lady! Cocks bodikins, you mistake him 'tis the new way of making Love, he's a spark of the times Lady, and Courts A-la-mode.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Mr. Easy I know you mean well, and for your Ladies sake, who is a vertuous Gentlewoman, you are always welcome to my House, your Kinsman too, I lookt upon as a proper Gentleman, and one that I was Redivable too, for the passion he profest to me, but now he has discover'd so disagreeable a quality, that really I am forc't to say I do not like his conversation, nor his address.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Address Lady? I know not what you mean by address, but I am sure his Estate is worth a thousand pound per annum, and a better penny, and do you talk of his address?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p:
Uncle say no more, leave her to her own peevish humour,
and the bare imagination of so likely a young fellow as my self. Widdow I am resolved to have thee my way, or no way, so adieu dear Widdow, I have other game in hand, beside, tolerated going to't, and so farewell Widdow.
Exit. Courtwell.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Kinsman, come back I say.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Sir, 'tis in vain, let him go, for I am resolv'd never to dispose of my self that way, this is my final resolution.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p:
Is it so, then your Nephew, young Mr. Amorous, shall never have my Neece Grace, and that's my final resolution.
Exit. Easy.

div.stage: Enter at the other door Mrs. Easy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Sweet Mrs. Woodbee, your Servant, what looks are these that cloud your smiles to day! What's the matter Friend?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Mrs. Easy I beg your pardon really, I did not see you, I have been so ill treated by some friends of yours â€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Of mine! let me know who they are, and Ile secure you Ile own e'm to be no more so.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: On my Conscience thou wilt keep thy word, for 'twas thy most filthy Husband.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: My Husband! Nay I believe it, for in good earnest Mrs. Woodbee, he is kind and civil to no body, nay, if you knew the daily, aye, and nightly torment too I have from him, you wou'd not wonder at his incivility to you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Nay, I believe indeed, you have very slender comfort of him, but alas, what can you expect from an old fusty fellow, that is even past the years of wishing well to our Sexâ€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: You are in the right, Lord if I could but tell you the story of all my sufferings of that kind, but I ought not to complain, when there's no hopes left of remedy. sighs.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: So, I hope I have an occasion to be reveng'd on this Husband of hers, and help contrive his being made a Cuckold, Hang me, if I am not infinitely rais'd with the thoughts on't, ah sweet Vengeance! how I love thee! (aside)

Come, I am no Woman if I don't fancy what thou'lt be at, nay, and 'tis but just and reasonable: 'Slife for Women of our youth, and all that, to languish away in sickly imagination; No, no, thou shalt
make use of what Nature has bestow'd on thee, so much Beauty to be buried alive, with an old rotten Carcass.â€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: What do you mean Madam?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: That, which thou mean'st. Come Friend I know thy Soul, thou shalt Cuckold this Fellow.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: How! Cuckold my Husband, forbid it!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Husband! Why what vertue is there in that Name, does the old Fool act like one? What duty of a Husband do you receive from him, ha?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: That indeed is true. But â€”

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I know you Married him out of humour, because you were in Love with another Man, but that Man, you have never yet confest to me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: That shan't be long a secret, dear Friend, if this counsel you give me, proceed from your real thoughts?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: So, let me thrive in the like success, when I have so great a provocation as thou hast, if I be not in earnest, I say agen enjoy thy self. I say be kind, be gay, and live for ever.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: And be a Whore? I blush to name it!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I see thou'rt willing, and I long to be reveng'd on the Insolency of thy Husband. (aside) Why look ye Mrs. Easy? You may call your self what you please, but so long as you can keep your own Counsel, you are pure, and unstain'd in the eyes of all the World.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: I confess, when I look upon Mr. Easy as a very useless Man to me, and how little Felicity I enjoy with him, I cannot scruple much at the thing propos'd. And therefore to be plain with you, I must own there is a Man, and such a Man â€”

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I such a Man, I like, forward â€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: 'Tis the same that once made honourable Love to me, but he had no Fortune, and I, not much, which parted us; And he has since, (by what good fortune I know not) rais'd himself in the World, for he's full of Money, which, manag'd by a strange liberality natural to him, is every day sacrific'd to me in Presents, and many entertainments.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Now thou speak'st as if thou understood'st thy self.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: He is beside a Gentleman, young, and infinitely agreeable.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: 'Slife thou'lt make me Rival thee.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: He is extreamly solicitous for a meeting, I mean such a one, as may afford him, all I have to give. Hides her face

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: And hast thou the heart to refuse him this?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Conscience, Conscience, Madam!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Away, with those silly thoughts, come, if thou bee'st certain of his Love, recompence it for shame.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: I receiv'd a Letter from him this very Morning, and I vow, I need counsel how to answer it, for 'tis to meet him this Evening in St. Iame's Parkâ€”Here's the Letter. Gives her the Letter.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Before I read it, I protest you shall promise to meet him, nay, and as he desires too, or loose my Friendship for an unwitty Woman.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Well, you have prevail'd, Ile swear to you to follow your Counsel.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Well said, now Ile see in what pleasing stile he writes.

p.hi: Madam, 'tis strange, that after so many Vows, and protestations, you should still remain an Infidel! Why is it? You will force me to some Extravagance that unbecomes a Man, and the secrecy of that Flame I have for you, to express my Soul in: For Loves sake, for mine, whom once you said, you lov'd, and more, for your own Honours sake, force me not into a stark madness that will undo us all.

sp.p: I vow he writes most passionately, oh do not force him to any despair, but be kind â€” Well, Ile read it out.

p.hi: You have a Husband, and I have (Hell take e'm) other concerns too, that require my secret carrying on of this affair of Love. Therefore meet me this Night in St. James's Pel Mal, or expect to have me dead, or worse to morrow.

sp.p: Ha! It cannot be! Lovechange! 'Tis Witchcraft, this, Lovechange, Hell! 'Tis not his hand, oh but I am too well assur'd it isâ€”Let me disguise my Rage, and strive against Nature. aside

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Well, what think you of't Madam?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I think all Men are false, and that Woman whose honour is trusted in their hands, a ruin'd thing.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p:
Have you met with ought there that has wrought this
sudden change in you, if Women be not as false too, then how came you thus alter'd? Was it to get this secret of my Life from me, and then betray it? Bad Woman, farewell. Offers to go.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.p: She must not go thus, nor must I discover, [aside] Mrs. Easy, come, be not angry with me, nor suspect me, your Letter only made me call to mind some former passages of my Life, In which I was betraid; 'Twas such another Man as this you have describ'd, and such a Letter too, betray'd me, once, to ruine, but you may keep your word, for this perhaps is real. [aside] Ile counterplot you though.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: If there be truth in Man, this cannot erre, and believe he speaks all truths to me.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: It may be so to you, but false to me, as thou art to thy Honour. Aside.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Madam, Methinks I find a sudden alteration in you, I am sorry I have occasion'd it, pardon my ignorance.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Indeed you have put a melancholly thought into me, but 'twil not last.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Ile take my leave, it may be you wou'd be alone, when you are dispos'd for't, Ile come and let you know my Adventure with Lovechange.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p:
Oh how she stabs me! as if she'd sound the mortal vein, (aside) your servant sweet Mrs. Easy, however you leave me now, I assure you the Relation of that Amorous adventure, will be very Cordial to me, as I shall order the matterâ€”
Exit Mrs. Easy Now Wit and Woman help me!
Enter Clare.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Here's your Kinsman Mr. Amorous, Madam.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Let him come in.
How now Nephew, thou look'st ill upon't.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: As well as a successless Lover can do.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What still whining after Mrs. Grace? Ile tell you Nephew, I'de rather thou should'st never marry, then be oblig'd to that old fool Easy for thy admittance.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p:
Madam, I was the most acceptable pretender, but I know not what Devil has possest him; For he comes into her Chamber just now, and finding me there, very full of choller, forbade me her presence, and his house, and told me what Treatment Mr. Courtwell
found from you, I should receive there for the future.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: He has done well, I tell thee, I hate him, take a secret which thou know'st not. This fellow being vastly rich, had got my good will to marry me, the day was assign'd, the things provided; Over night, he by chance saw a woman of something (as she, and he thought) a better Face, and married her. This, from my Pride, I do so stomach that I can never forgive.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Yet, you seem to be very kind to the Lady, Madam?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I do so, and will revenge the affront I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: But Madam, though you love not him, let not the Neece in your opinion inherit the crimes of the Uncle, give me leave to adore her, for she's all sweet and innocent.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I am not so ill natur'd, but I will say, that if without her Uncles leave you can gain her, (for I scorn thou should'st be a suitor to him for any thing) I give my consent, for besides my aversion to the old Man, I have a secret Reason not to marry Courtwell, which you shall know hereafter. I have some affairs of my own to dispatch before Night.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Madam Ile follow your directions in all things.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Cousin, I had forgot to tell you, that there is a young Man, a Person of Quality, arriv'd from Spain, from your Uncle there, he has made my house his home, and pray treat him kindly.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: I shall obey you Madam.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I am very glad Madam, that you are at last resolv'd to oblige Mr. Lovechange, Ile swear he's almost wild for your answer.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: When will he call for't?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Madam, he's walking here hard by, or will be immediately, have you writ?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: No, but you may let him know my mind, that is, that I will be in the Mall, as soon as it begins to be dark, if I can get from my Husband.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Oh Lord Madam! Now I think on't, we look for Sir Ralph Spatter to night, Mrs. Graces Sweet-heart, and my Master designs to make a Masquerade as they call it, on purpose to entertain him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p:
That's true, some way must be contriv'd to cheat him
of my Company. For Peg, now I have resolv'd upon't, I cannot forbear going, had my Husband been any thing approaching to Man, I shou'd have believ'd I had long'd, so great is my desire of seeing Lovechange to night. Oh, this dear Letter has so powerful an attraction, that I must go. Kisses the Letter.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Some way we'l find out. O dear Madam, here's my Master in Rancour, for I had forgot to tell you forsooth, that he has forbid Mr. Amorous the house, and that Mrs. Grace is full of dolour.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Easy, snatches the Letter out of Mrs. Easy's hand.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: What's this I pray?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: I am undone! Nay I protest you must not see't for the World, it is a new Song.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Some bawdy Lampoon, Ile warrant ye, Ile see't.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p:
Ile protest it is not Sir, when 'tis set you shall hear it sung.
Enter Grace weeping.
She's come in very good time. Alas! poor Cousin Grace, and have you Sir, can you be so cruel to Cousin Grace, pray let her have the Man she loves.â€” Peg, hast never a Song to change this for? Aside.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, but 'tis a very scurvy one.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: I say Ile see the Paper.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Any thing dear Peg, but the Letter, Aside come Dear will you consider Graece?

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: The Verses I say, I smell a Plot, 'tis some Love Letter, come, come, produce, produce.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: I vow Dear I am asham'd you shou'd see e'm, they are so very silly.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I Sir, and somethingâ€”

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Bawdy too, Ile warrant ye, let's see, let's see.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Truly Sir, my Mistress has not read e'm yet.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: What's here, Sigâ€” Sig, Signiorâ€” hey day, what's the Devil got amongst you two: I shall Signior ye, and you want a Signior.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: What say you concerning Grace Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: I say you are all naught, and 'tis time you had all Men, lusty Men, able Men, for the Devil will supply their places else, and therefore I design to morrow, to marry Grace to a young lusty Lad, and a Knight, de ye see a Knight.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: How Sir, marry me, and not to Mr. Amorous?

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Amorous! Let me but see thee peep through the Window upon Amorous agen, and Ile make a Nun of thee, dost hear, where thou shalt languish with the thought of flesh, and every day shall be a Good-Friday to thee.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: You will not be so inhumane, will you Sir? you have the liberty to chuse Youth and Beauty here in my Aunt, and despis'd Riches as the most unvaluable thing; and can you believe I am so unlike you to chuse Wealth and an empty Title before so much Worth as dwells in Mr. Amorous.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: If I have play'd the Fool, I do not mean you shall do so too. I have a Wife indeed of Youth and Beauty, but had I known the continual Plague of keeping her honest, she shou'd e'n have been left to her old Gallant Lovechange, perhaps his Youth without my Money, had made her take the same courses, that my Money, and no Youth does, but I have rid my hands of him, thanks be prais'd.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: This is unkind Mr. Easy to upbraid me with so innocent a kindness as I had for Mr. Lovechange.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Nay, now I dare swear for thee, but yet I cannot help fearing, for Sweetheart he is very much spruc'd up of late, that is, since you were married, goes Rich, and spends high; notable signs, that some old Fool, or other may have a handsome liberal Wife, but thou art truly honest. Well, we do every moment expect Sir Ralph Spatter, pray let there be musick got, and let the young Folks dance, invite Mrs. Lay-it-on, and Mrs. Frisker, and who else you please, and their Husbands, and entertain his Worship after the London fashion, Ile have it handsome.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Madam, i'me undone if your goodness don't assist me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Fear not, Ile warrant we'l take some care, I know too well the torment of forc'd Marriages to wish thee that punishment, but Cousin, pray do you see all things got in order to night, for I have a visit, or two, to make of concern.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p:
Madam, you shall command me.
Exit Mrs. Easy.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir, here's a Gentleman inquires for you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Bodikins, 'tis Sir Ralph, bring him in.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I believe it is Sir. Exit Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Sirrah, go you and look out Mr. Lovechange, and let him know I am come to Town, and shall have need of that small sum of money he owes me. Exit Boy.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Sir Ralph, I am yours, and heartily glad to see you.

sp.speaker: Sir Lalph.
sp.p:
Sir, I am as much yours, and as glad to see you, and so I am to see you forsooth.
To Mrs. Grace.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: 'Tis more then I am to see you, Ile promise ye.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Oh cry ye mercy, then you are not the Lady I took you for, I thought you had been Mrs. Grace my Mistress?

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: That's her name Sir, and her quality.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Truly Uncle, that must be, if she have no better, you are much too blame for giving her no better education, I thought she wou'd have receiv'd me with open arms, for though I say it, I deserve it, and understand breeding.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: I doubt it Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: You can't oblige me more, then to question my ability, for then you give me occasion to show my parts, and first as touching the Art of Courtship, though I don't read Romances, Plays, Histories, Pastoralls, or Farces, yet can accost a Lady after this sort â€” Madam, (with my Face scru'd up thus) I am your proud Servitor, or in English proud to serve you, my hands beneath your feet, is too mean a sacrifice; go where you will, I am your shadow, advance but the standard of your eyes, and i'm your Captive, your Creature, your very Frogg, begot, by your gentle influence. P'shaw I am furnish'd with a thousand things of the like nature.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Rare, rare, I vow, ah Sir Ralph, were I a young Wench for your sake, I cou'd hug you, and love you all over.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Pray do so for me Sir, for I find no one part of him to move me to't.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Madam, if I were you, I wou'd dissemble with him a little.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: I had as good do so indeed Betty.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: A little time, will make her plyable.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: P'shaw, I don't question that mun, what do you think Mrs. Grace?

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Sir, I hope time will convince me of my errour, and let me see, that you have perfections, which are yet disguis'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: I thank you Mrs. Grace, for your good opinion of me I vow, and shall I hope do well against to morrow.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: 'Twere unkind Sir, to forbid your hope.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Well then, Ile set my seal upon you, in sign and token that you are my own. kisses her.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Go, now Grace, you may withdraw, get things in a readiness against night.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p:
I obey you Sir.
Exit Grace.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Sir, I must crave your excuse for a few moments, I am going to call in a little Money, an ill office to play the Dun, but you know Sir, we Lovers that have peevish Mistresses to deal with, require more than bare Courtship, well adieu Sir.

div.stage: Exit Sir Ralph one way, Mr. Easy the other.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p:
This is my constant walk three times a day, pray Heaven the Neighbourhood don't take me for some walking spright, that upon certain hours, comes to give some intelligence of hid treasure.
Enter Peg.
But here's Peg, now dear Soul, what answer dost bring me? Shall I see my Mistress? Shall I be happy this night?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I know not how happy 'twill make you, but she will be this night in the Mall, at the upper end.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Dear Maid, Ile owe thee the Indies for this.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I Sir, if you did but know, what shift my Mistress makes, you wou'd think your self oblig'd and indebted too I can assure you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: No more, here's an earnest of what I owe thee, prithee give her my service, my Love, my Heart, and Soul, honest Peg.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Oh lass, what shall I do, here comes Sir Ralph Spatter, Mrs. Graces Sweet-heart; who by no means must see me.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Why I hope he's no Rival.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: No Sir, but he may hereafter know me, for he's a Suitor to Mrs. Grace.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p:
Leave me then, for I have a message from him, and will take this opportunity to speak to him.
Exit Peg.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Mr. Lovechange your Servant, I sent to you just now, and a â€¢ glad to meet you, you know my business Sir.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I know you pretend I owe you a thousand pounds but I am not provided with such a sum at present.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Sir, I shou'd not have given you this trouble now, and at so short warning, but that I am upon my marriage, and there are a thousand Perquisits, and Trangams requir'd, in order to the gaining my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Save your money Sir Ralph, save your money, for this is no time to present idle Women, they are vain enough of themselves, do not raise them.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: I, but Sir, we that are Lovers, must do these idle foolish things, or loose those more foolish idle things call'd Women.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: If all Lovers, are to walk by one Rule, then Sir I am in the same predicament with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Why, are you going to marry too?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Faith, no Sir, I thank my Stars, but I am as much in Love, as those that are.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p:
Well Sir, I am a little in haste now, pray think of the Debt, your Servant Sir.
Exit Sir Ralph.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Pox of that foolish noddle of his, to believe i'le ever pay that Debt, which I was trappan'd into, by the old Rogue his Fathers cunning? as long as I have a Woman in my eye, no, no, my designs can't be carried on with empty Pockets.

div.stage: Enter a Porter with a Letter.

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: I think Sir, your name is Mr. Lovechange.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: The sameâ€” From whom, this?

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: The Contents will inform you.

sp.speaker: Lov.

body.p: Dear Lovechange for some reasons that I must tell you, I have thought fit to alter my design of meeting you in the Mall, but will wait your coming at the side of the Duck-pond under those Trees, on the Bank.

sp.p: I like the Resolution well, tell the Person from whom you come, I will not fail to be at the place appointed. Exeunt severally.

div.trailer: The End of the First Act.

div.head: Actus Secundus,
Scena Prima.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: YOu are sure the Porter gave it into his own hand?

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Yes Madam, and he said he would not fail to meet you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Well Lovechange, I will be reveng'd, and innocently so, perfidious man, whom I married without Fortune, or Friends, believing that way to oblige thee, but thou ungrateful as thou art, mak'st no returns, but false ones, but at least I will possess thee once more in revenge to both, and then scorn, and abandon thee to thy former arts of living.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Well, I can't but think Madam, how mad Mrs. Easy will be, when she knows the trick put upon her.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Let her fret, till she grow old, but Clare I am not content to deprive her of all she expects this night in Lovechange, but I wou'd have it known, and at once kill the old Cuckold, and destroy her Pride.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Oh Madam, I have it just now alighted in my Brain: you know Madam, Mr. Courtwell makes love to you, and so he does to all Woman-kind by turns.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Yes, 'tis a loose Gallant, but what of him?

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Why Madam, the next time he comes to wait on you.â€”

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I have given him his answer, he'l trouble me no moreâ€” but suppose he shou'd â€” for I begin to conceive a Project.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Pray Madam let me speak first, for fear it shou'd be the very same I have, and I claim the priviledge of a discoverer: Madam, this very Man Mr. Courtwell, will I send to meet Mrs. Easy instead of your Husband Mr. Lovechange.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I like the thing, and 'tis the very same with mine, but how to effect it? I fear we shan'not meet with Courtwell, I wou'd not wish for a madder fellow, nor a more talkative.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Madam, walk off, for yonder's Mr. Courtwell, as pat as if the Devil had sent him for the purpose.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p:
I'le leave thee to thy wit, and him.
Exit Woodbee.

div.stage: Enter Courtwell walking, Clare walks by carelesly.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: What's here a Prize, at this time of the dayâ€” Mrs. if a Man should beg leave of you to take a turn or so?

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Two, or Three, if you please Sirâ€”

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Kind, and gentleâ€” imbraces her.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: And your Servant Clare Sir.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Ah! sweet Mrs. Clare, faith I am turns up her Hood. glad to meet thee, and how, and how, what shall we take a Bottle? come Clare, thou should'st be kind, and Ile be grateful, come, I can lead thee, the back way into the Bull-head Tavern, and we'l be merry for half an hour.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Tavern Sir, what to do?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Only to drink thy Ladies health, Clare, no harm at all I protest Clare.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: You wou'd be making Love I warrant too?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: A little Love Clare, for exercise only, alas, we that are young and brisk cannot live without it.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Why Sir, I do yet understand, but little of that my self, but I know a Lady Sirâ€”

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: 'Pho thou talk'st of future joysâ€” but I am for a little of the present, come dear Clare, be kind, upon my honour I have had a passion for thee a long time, and will be as constant, nay i'le swear to have no other Miss, but thee, and will keep thee as fine as e're a Miss about the Town Egad now.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: What, and pretend to my Lady Sir?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: That's for a necessary thing, call'd a Wife, but thou Clare, shalt share with her.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: For a whole week at least.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: By my troth, and a fair time too I take it.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Come Sir, you'd better drive the other bargain with me?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: What, for the Lady thou speak'st of, if thou could'st bring it to pass suddenly, much might be said, but I hate delays.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: This Evening Sir.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Now I hear thee, her name and parts, I prithee.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: You may know more in good time â€” but thus much now, she's exceeding Beautiful, Young, and Innocent.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: No too much of the last, I pray.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Sir, to speak the naked truth, she is â€”

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Lovely, as Woman in the same conditionâ€”

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: No, but I vow Sir, I lye not, she's exceding handsome, well shap't, delicate fine, tall, virtuous, and â€”

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: The Devil and all, whither wilt thou carry her, to the degree of an Angel?

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Besides, she's Rich, and needs none of your presents, nor keeping Sir.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Oh thou hast ravisht me, I am all on Fire, for Heavens sake, sweet Clare, let me have this Nymph to allay my Flames?

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: But Sir, I thought you had been in love with me?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I, I, Clare, I am in love with thee too, but this Lady, Clare, ha! where does she live Girl?

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Look Sir, if I bring you together, I have done my part.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I, I, that shall suffice, let me alone for the rest, and reward thee.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Well then Sir, about eight of the Clock this Evening, here in the Mall, you shall find her in the upper end all alone, she is so, and so drest, of a good mean, and shape, not very tall. whispers

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: All this I like, but is this pure kindness to me Clare, hast thou no design, no trick to put upom me? or like the Devil, dost thou only inrich me to damn my Soul hereafter.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Why, to tell you the plain truth Sir, I have an end in't, and that is a little Revenge only, for Sir this Lady is to meet Mr. Lovechange there.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Lovechange! A very Tyger at a Woman, introth thou art kind to the Lady, and putst her into gentler hands by far, but Clare, what spite have you to Lovechange?

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Now, what shall I say? â€”Why truly Sir â€” He â€” aside made a little love to me once, and the truth on't is, though I did not love him so well as to do â€”

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: What, what Clare?

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: That Sir; nay you make me blush I vow, yet I had such a smackering for him, as will carry me to this innocent revenge.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p:
A plague on her, what does she call innocent, to rob a man of the enjoyment of the finest Woman in Town, (aside) well Clare,
Heavens blessing, and this â€” go along with thee. gives her Money. But not a word of this to your Lady.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Adieu Mr. Courtwell, I warrant you for secresie.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Now will I go, and dress me as like Lovechange as I can, for I suppose that will please her best, here's the Rogue himself.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Oh, your Servant Mr. Courtwell, how thrives your Amour with the Widow, ha! what is she kind, and coming?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Time has worn out, even the very thoughts of all those things in her, I think, which â€” because I can't forbear telling her, does so incense her, as the truth is Ned, I believe it will not be a match:

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Oh, will it not so? Well I hope, like the Sea, what you loose in one place, you gain in another.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Faith no, that grand concern of the World, making love, is quite laid by with me, I find none that are kind, but at so unmerciful a rate â€”

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Thou art a miserable man, that canst not get the knack on't, for William, there be Ladies, yes there be Ladies, that will, and can love, look ye. shows a Letter.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Oh, you are a happy man Sir.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: So might'st thou, did'st thou but use my Arts:

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Prithee, what be they?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Swearing, Lying, and shamming in abundance.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Poh, all this, I dayly practice, but 'tis bootless.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Thou dost overdo't, or underdo't, there is a certain quantity goes to the charm, thou wilt find it out in timeâ€” there is a Lady Willâ€” Egad, such a dear Soulâ€” that has a passion for me.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Oh, I doubt it not Sir.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: And this night begins my Heaven, for I shall possess her Will, dost hear? possess her Lad.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Then, I rather think 'twil end your Heaven, for you'l care but little for her after that.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Of, that Ile give you a better account to morrow, I writ a Letter to her to day to meet me here this Evening, and I am so impatient, that I can't forbear the place, till the hour come.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: And what, is this the Garb you have design'd to entertain her in?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Even this.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Well, I congratulate your good fortune Sir.

sp.speaker: Peg,
sp.p: I have been to inquire for you, and they told me, you were here in the Park.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I vow thou mak'st my heart ake, prithee let me hear thy message, quick, and put me out of my pain, I hope thy Mistress will come?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Yes Sir, and I only forgot to tell you how my Lady is drest, and therefore came to let you know Sir, she'l beâ€” whispers.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: She need not fear, I shan't mistake her for any other, besides, she will be in so remote a part of the Park, that I suppose there will be hardly any but her self.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Lord Sir, what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Mean? To meet thy Lady, and all the bliss I expect in this World.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: But where Sir?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: By the Duck-Pond side.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: What do you mean Sir? Are you not to meet her in the Mall? here, in this very place, where you now are?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: No, dear Soul, did not I receive a Letter just now from her to the contrary: That she desir'd to change the place for some reasons, best known to her self? here, read it thy self.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Duck-Pond side â€” for Reasonsâ€” ha, ha, ha â€” This my Ladies hand?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Why dost laugh Reprobate?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I wou'd I were married, if this be'nt an errant cheat, well, faith I laugh, but have more need to cry, to think how we poor Women are treated by you false men, now have you been boasting your good fortune to some kind hearted Lass, that's jealous of you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: The Devil take me Peg â€”

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Hold Sir, don't swear, how cou'd this come about else? Oh that ever my Lady shou'd trust you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p:
By Heaven, thou wilt make me rave, I have not seen a Woman,
nor will I see a Woman, whilst I have breath but thy Lady, Hell take me if I have nam'd her, but to the Air in sighs, and sure this must be hers.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Believe me Sir, she wou'd not trust this secret to any but my self.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: 'Twas a Porter brought it me as I was walking here, and now I do believe 'tis some trick, therefore pray inform her, that according to her first order, i'le meet her in the Mall, here at the furthest end.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p:
Ile let her know you will Sir, your servant.
Exit Peg.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: What's all this communication?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p:
About a mistake, this is the servant to that Lady I must meet at night, in order to which I must take my leave.
Exit Lovechange

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p:
Your servant Ned, good luck attend thee, now if I can but get here before him, and lead the Lady off, I shall be a double conquerour.
Exit. Courtwell.

div.head: Scene Third.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. Easy, Grace, and Betty.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Now I have told you Madam, how much I love, you'l judge at my unhappiness.

It may be, you have been a Lover too, and then I cannot doubt your pitty Madam, I don't entertain you as an Aunt, our years are equal, and perhaps our hearts, but as a Sister, and a friend, I sue, and beg you wou'd afford me your assistance.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: I was your friend before I was your Aunt, and wish I had remain'd in that blest state, without advancing farther.
Far from the joys of Youth, and Love, i'me gone, but thou art wise, hold where thou art dear Grace, and wed thy self to something like thy self, despise Sir Ralph, and take young Amorous.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Oh Madam, how you do revive my Soul, this goodness in you, shows you just, as fair; but Madam, whence shall I derive my hopes; my Uncle's too severe, he won't suffer me to take my liberty abroad, nor here, and how can I find time to speak with Amorous: who languishes with me by sympathy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: This night your Uncle does design an entertainment: we'l be in Masquerade, Betty shall find out Amorous, and let him come also, mask't, none will know him, and if it be possible, get away with him, I conceive the project easie.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Most probable too, oh dear Madam! how I am oblig'd to your advice, and permission.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p:
Now I have instructed you, i'le be no more seen in your company to night, farewel, think of nothing but Amorous; whilst I prepare for Lovechange: [aside]
Exit Mrs. Easy

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Come Betty, follow me to my Closet for a Letter, if Prayers can help us, the gods shall want no sacrifice. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Sir, I am infinitely oblig'd to you for your goodness to me an unhappy stranger, and when you know how much I deserve your pitty too, I don't doubt but you will give it me.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Nothing Sir that you can suffer, can deserve pitty, unless you be a Lover.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Sir, I am a Lover, and so distrest a one â€”

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Dare you not oblige me with the knowledge on't?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Twou'd be too tedious, and too melancholly, and none but Lovers can a judgement make of what a Lover feels, therefore excuse me Sir.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: To let you know, how great my sence can be Ile tell you I can love as well as any, nay, and compare my miseries with yours, I love a Lady Sir, whose youth, and beauty, make all Captives that but look upon her, 'tis such a Treasure, that had Iason known, he wou'd have let his golden Fleece alone, to have made a Rape on her, and like that too, 'tis guarded by so strange a monstrous Beast, an old decripped Miser Uncle, that 'tis more difficult to charm his will, then fight a thousand Draggons, the Neeces full consent, and heart i've won, but am forbid to love by this old man.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: What reasons can he give for this severity?

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p:
He makes no objections against my Estate, or Person, for I
am sole heir to my Aunt, and all the hope of being so to that Uncle too; which you know in Spain.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Your Person Sir, is far from being disgustful, 'tis rather to be admir'd, and lov'd what can the reason be?

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Why Sir, he has a Nephew, call'd Mr. Courtwellâ€”

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Heavens! What of him? aside

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Who is design'd by this old testy man, to marry with my Aunt, she's rich, and as you see, not disagreeable.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: What will this come to? aside

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: But she for some reasons refuses him, yet he is worthy, young, and rich.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Does she refuse him Sir? Oh false Dissembler. aside

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: You seem disturb'd Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Yes Sir, to think that no merits, no parts, though even Divine, can take a heart inflexible, my Case was so, but does he love her much?

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: For her riches only, her wealth, he courts, not her, cou'd he but gain her, I shou'd then be happy, for his Uncle declares, I shall be welcome to his Neece, when Courtwell is receiv'd well by my Aunt, of if he wou'd cease his Courtship, and make it elsewhere, in time, the old man might be reduc'd.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I know this Courtwell, and will try my Arts to make him alter his, as well as his Uncles will, believe me Sir, I once had power o're him, and I will try and use it now for both your services.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: I don't distrust your vertue, nor your will, pray see, what you can do, and let me be honour'd, with the Title of your friend.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Sir, I am proud of the glory, and am your faithful Servant.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Sir, I have a message to you, besides this. gives him a Letter

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Welcome dear messenger of Love, oh how you bless my Soul.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: You speak as if you were sure it brought love, and good News.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Nothing from this hand can be ungrateful! Reads 'Tis enough, yes I will come, though Hell oppos'd my passage Betty, thou know'st the contents of this, and must assist my just design.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Has my Mistress sent you word what habit she'l be in?

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.p: She has, but without that help, my heart would find her out, pray tell her how impatiently I long for the wish'd for moment.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Sir, that you may imploy your self to advantage till then, you were best to provide the means to carry her away handsomely, and think of a place, where.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Oh Betty, trouble not your self for that, if fortune be so kind to me, to put her into my hands, Ile warrant her safety there, Ile defie Fate, to ravish her â€¢â€¢ ence, keep but thy Mistress in this happy humour, and I don't fear success.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Well Sir, it grows dark, and I shall be wanted, Ile say all the kind things I can, and which I am sure you think, to Mrs. Grace, and so farewell Sir â€”

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Oh Betty, thou canst not think what I wou'd say, nor I can't utter it, but let Grace imagine, she loves, and knows my Soul to be intirely hers, I will not fail a moment, and so disguis'd, as none but she shall know me. Exeunt severally

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: I wonder Peg, who this shou'd be, that has put this trick upon us, and sent the note to Lovechange?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Some of his Ladies from Wildstreet Alley, or some other such part of the Town.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: I cannot believe he wou'd reveal it to any, I have had many proofs of his prudence, and love, though no use of his secresie, till this hour, pray Heaven I don't repent it.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: P'shaw, what at your repentance already, good Madam, don't think of it, but go boldly on.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Well, I'le be at the upper end of this Walk, but I am so impatient, that I wou'd have you go through the Guard, and see for him.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p:
You need not doubt his speed, but however Ile go.
Exit Peg.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: This must be the Lady â€” [aside] Madam is it you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: I have sent Peg just now through the Guards to look for you; which way came you?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: By a Key the other way, now what shall I entertain her with for a beginning?
A pox on't, I shall spoil all I fear, if I talk much, and I cannot come right down to the matter. aside

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: You are thoughtfull, Mr. Lovechange, what is it some device to excuse the mistake of the Letter? Oh Lovechange! I cou'd not believe, you wou'd have treated my first kindness to you, in this ungrateful sort.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: What shall I answer now? some kind Devil assist me! [aside] Oh Madam, he that can be false to you, is a Reprobate to Heaven, and durst not aspire to the bounties of your love â€” but Madam â€” I am out again (aside) will you believe my Vows and Oaths? â€” By your divine self, by all that's â€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Hold, I must, I will believe you.
Ah Lovechange, you little think with what fear I come to yeild you up my Honour, after believing you false â€”But come you must dispose of me, I can't resist.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p:
Nay, if you be thereabouts already, I am happy enough: [aside] Madam don't destroy our pleasures with fears of any thing, for by all that's good I am intirely yours, come, whither shall I lead you, I am impatient.
Enter Peg.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Madam, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Stay, here's my Woman has something to say to me.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Mr. Lovechange is coming Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Coming! whether is he coming tro?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: To you Madam, as fast as he can.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Fool, he's here already.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Already! where?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Why, there thou Dunce.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: He mounted a Cloud then, for I'me sure I saw him paying his Coach, and spoke to him, told him where you were, and run before, to give you notice.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Thou art stark mad, I have entertain'd him this half hour, here.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Lord Madam, 'tis the greatest mistake in the World, I vow this is some forlorn, or other, that making a discovery of the Enemy unguarded, fell on, believe me Madam, 'tis none of Mr. Lovechange.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Who the Devil shou'd it be then? Well 'tis a mercy I had not discover'd all to him.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: If you have been together this half hour, I fear you have discover'd too much â€” 'Slife â€” I have it, I fancy this must be some body concern'd in the Intrigue of the Letter sent to Mr. Lovechange.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Faith it may be so, Ile try, and fit him for't.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Madam, you forget, that I am impatient of delay, what's all this whispering for?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: My Woman informs me, that some of my Relations are in the Mall, and 'tis possible may know me, therefore dear Lovechange, retire to some remote place of the Park.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Madam, I obey you, with joy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: The Duck-Pond side, I think most convenient; But for our beter security, go you about that way, Ile go this, and meet you.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I take your word, and will be there before you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.l:
I believe you will, if at all?
Exit Courtwell.
Oh the villany of Man!

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.l: Oh th Wit of Woman! Madam, I adore your contrivance.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: My Lovechange!

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: My dearest Mistress!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Oh I know that voice 'tis musick to my Soul, aside that I shou'd be so dull, not to distinguish the false one, from the true! Well dear Lovechange, let's withdraw to some other part of the Park less open, for I have many eyes to watch me.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: This overcharge of joy arrives too hastily, I shou'd have time to let it enter by degrees.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: No ceremonious Foppery dear Lovechange! our joys require some hast, but something Peg, I have to say to thee first, here take this Key, and dress your self in my Masking habit, and represent me this Evening, Ile trust thy management of the business, and thy Wit to deceive the old Man.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Let me alone Madam, to act you to the life, till Bed time at least.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Nay, I think thou may'st venture thy Maiden-head without danger, there too.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p:
I think, for any great massacre he has made of yours, I may; well Ile run, for fear of the worst.
Exit Peg.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Come my fair Mistress, whilst thus I bear you off, to reap the joys of Love, I find more happiness, more real argument for glorious pride, then if Tryumphant Lawrel deckt my Brow, to speak me Conquerour of Monarchys? Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Woodbee from one side, and Courtwell from the other, meeting.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Well Madam, I find you are a Woman of Honour, and have kept your word, and then I need not doubt of all the happiness I wish beside.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Oh how my heart rises at this false Man, but I must dissemble it. aside
I vow Mr. Lovechange, 'tis well you can't see me blush, for I confess I am not us'd to these encounters.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Come, come, fair one, no sence of shame I beseech you, for that will call the blood up to thy face, which shou'd be active in another part, oh that dear thought, faith and troth makes me impatient: Come, come where shall we be, where, where, what think you of yonder Bench?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Oh intollerable! he never was thus kind to me before! nor would he now, if he knew all. aside

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Come, come, no study upon the matter.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Fye, fye, Mr. Lovechange, no approaches to the business; methinks there shou'd be some short Prologue of Courtship, before the Scene of Love begin.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Our youth, and vigour, needs none of all that, we are ready at all times.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I wou'd you were â€” Aside
Sir, you have prevail'd, and overcome, but methinks this Bench is a very undecent place.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Oh Madam I There has been many a worse shift made, the night, and these kind shades, secure our joys.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: But not your perfidiousness. aside
Ile swear Sir, you are so importune. Exeunt hand in hand

div.stage: Enter Mr. Easy, and Sir Ralph.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Come, come, Grace, Wife, Betty, Peg, where be all these Girls, there is such tricking, such licking, patching, and sinifying, that 'tis a shame to see't, and tedious to attend it, but to entertain you, we'l have a Song.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p:
With all my heart Uncle.
A Song.
Poor honest Fool, I wonder what I meant?
When in the Marriage Circle, first I went.
What Magick's in that Name?
What pow'rful conjuration, can there be,
Or where's that too, too happy she,
That can allay Love â€” when 'tis Legion.
Yet for a quiet Life I've often dy'd,
But oft my Wife has Murdered me beside:
So slyly too, she did the deed,
That at my Murderers sight, I cou'd not bleed:
Though a Phillis new inspires,
At once Life, and whole troops of fresh desires.
And yet shou'd I be constant stillâ€”I will,
Yes like a Rock and like that too, Ile take
Each Wave that near me breaks:
And ravish't gently, for her cruel sake:
There Ile drink, and quaff, and ryot:
They're sickly Souls that keep more constant dyet.
Very well, I vow, and swear now.

div.stage: Enter Peg as Mrs. Easy, in Mask. Betty disguis'd like Grace, other Men and Women Mask'd, old Easy to Peg.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: My dear Wife, now I like thee, i'st not as good to be merry at home, as abroad?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Sir, I am all obedience, and like any place where you are.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p:
Why, thats well said, come, inform the Musick, and Ile make one, and you Sir Ralph take Grace here, come Grace, be a good Girl, and love Sir Ralph.
Gives him Betty.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Most judiciously tript, I vow and swear now, ha! little Mrs. Grace, come since you can wag your heels so prittily in a Dance, you'l wag something else in place where, Ile warrant ye, ha Rogue, thy handsome Leg, and Foot, has made me wish â€” you little think, what, I vow now.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Nor care to know Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: You lye like a pritty little Baggage faith now, you do know, and you shall know before anon, what say you Uncle?

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: I say, as you do Sir Ralph.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: I Sir, and in order to't, pray send for a Cushion Cuffer, that there may be no more shall I, shall I, in the Case, for all flesh is frail, and Women fickle. What say you Mrs. Grace.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I am all obedience.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p:
Come Ladies, and Gentlemen, I have a treat waits you within.
Enter Amorous disguis'd,

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: That must be she by her habit, and shape, Madam do you know me?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Do you know me?

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: My heart tells me I do, and yours might answer you.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Mr. Amorous,â€”Oh Sir my Mistress â€”

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: How's this!

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: What's this a Rival, oh Uncle a Rival, a Rival.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Cocks bodikins 'tis this impudent young Hector Amorous.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: How, Amorous? what's he? pray Uncle.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: One, that wou'd rob you of your Mistress. Sir Ralph, go and take her from him.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: I thank you for that, I make one of the worst bulleys in nature, I vow, pray Uncle do you handle him for me, he has a terrible grim look of his own.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Sir, pray who are you?

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: A troubled Spirit Sir, that still repairs to it's bright Treasure.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Oh are you so Sir? We shall conjure you, Uncle, Uncle.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: First Mistress, come you o'this sideâ€” take her away Sir Ralph.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: 'Tis not Amorous Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: I will not trust you, nor believe you, but who e're he be, we'l leave him to himself. Your Servant good Familiar.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: I, Sir your Servant, you see the Treasure's own'd, and you may please to walk, fare you well, fare you well.

div.stage: Enter to Amourous, Grace from behind the Hangings, Easy returns to the door.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Amorous, my faithful Friend!

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: What this? aside

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: My dearest Grace, 'twas kindly done to undeceive me quickly, why didst not tell me of thy plot?

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Because I wou'd surprize ye unawares, but dear Amorous, I have a plot for thee wholly necessary to our happiness, you must play the Parson, and marry this Fool to Betty, that we may have time for our escape, I have hid a habit within a purpose, haste dear Amorous, for our affairs require haste.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Oh rare Rogues, have I caught ye. aside.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Dear Grace, how I am oblig'd to thee for this contrivance, doubt not my management.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Ile wait behind these hangings for you. Exeunt.

div.trailer: The End of the Second Act.

div.head: Actus Tertius,
Scena Prima.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: NOw I defie my Rivals, if Amorous court thee now, Ile have an Action against him, I hate these fighting Fopps faith, that upon every occasion are at Sa â€” sa â€” A pox of their Valour; sirrah, court my mistriss if you dare, says one, for if thou dost, this shall proclaim my right, then to't they go, and there's a Lover lost, perhaps the others hang'd, the Drunken Fopp cryes dam ye, you dog, drink up your Glass, or you are not fit for civil Society; which if refus'd, to Tilting they go, and this they call an honourable quarrel. 'Tis likely three half pence well manag'd at an Apothecaryes, cures all the wounds they have, and they set up for men of Courage, brisk Bulleys of the Sword: These Grace, be the finest Blades of the Age, that court ye, and gain too, all the idle Women of the Town; and when a Country, down-right, honest, peaceable Knight, as I am, makes Love; we are laught at call'd Sir Martin, Sir Nicholas, and forty other ridiculous names; that the newest Comedies furnish ye withall; But Grace, I have money Grace, and a pox of formal Fopps.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Sir, you entertain me with things that concern me not.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Yes Grace, I wou'd have thee be wise now, thou art my Wife.

div.stage: Enter Easy, leading Grace from behind the Hangings.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Be these your tricks Mistriss, what you were hid to wait your Lover Amorous, were you? come along, or I will disgrace thee publickly.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: What's this, what's this, my Uncle, and Mrs. Grace, why who the Devil have I married here then?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Your Friend, and Servant Betty, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: How! why you have not cheated me thus, out of my sweet self have you? oh I'me undone, undone! cryes.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p:
How! Sir Ralph, married to Betty? Oh me, that I had but so much moisture in my whole body as wou'd keep you company
Sir Ralph, but since I have not, this baggage shall cry for meâ€”goâ€” get you in, and know your Commander.
Beats Grace in

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p:
Oh Betty I'me lost.
Exeunt Easy, Grace, and Sir Ralph.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: So, now I have resign'd my holy Habit, and am become a lay Lover agen.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: O Sir, my poor Mistriss was discover'd behind the Hangings, and her Uncle has treated her very ill for your sake.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Discover'd! oh Betty thou kill'st me! so near my wisht for Port, and sunk i'th very harbour. Malitious Stars!â€”

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Well Sir, I don't doubt but for all this, to bring it about agen, in the mean time, 'twere good you shou'd retire, I will give you notice of all that passes.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.l: I thank thee Betty, but I fear my Fate,
How near was I, to being Fortunate. Exeunt severally.

div.stage: Scene a Bed-chamber, a Table out, and a Chair.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: O Woman! monstrous Woman! Argus eyes quotha'! ye an hundred were not able to watch one Woman, a curse upon the whole Sex, and foolish Man for being so fond of 'em. Oh I am sick, very sick with fretting, ten years are taken from my time with this nights work, but I have her fast, and will as soon as day appears conjure her into better manners, oh my heart! But all my consolationis in thee my dear Wife. undresses himself.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: What the Devil shall I say, or do? I dare not turn my Face toward the light, least he shou'd know me, and if I speak, I fear that will betray me, if I refuse to go to Bed, I discover all my Mistresses secrets, and then we are undone, if I go to Bed â€” Why thenâ€”Heaven knows whatâ€” Aside

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: I am happy in this yet, that I in thee my Hony, have a loving Vertuous Wife, one that's above all the little Lightnesses of her Sex, yes, her villanous Sex, Come, come to Bed my Love.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Sir, since 'tis so near day, and you so hasty to take Revenge upon Grace, we had e'n as good save the labour of undressing.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: By no means, to Bed I say, that I may take a little repose, after this harasssing of my Spirits, but still I am thrice happy in thee.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Aye, wou'd you knew all â€” no hopes yetâ€” No Mistriss come, what shall I do? she is so taken up with her more soft affairs, that she minds not how rashly I am like to be us'd with this old Master of mine. aside

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Thou hast but one only fault, and that is, not loving thy Bed, prithee reform that lewd and scandalous way of life, of sitting up late.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Lord, that he shou'd blame any Woman, that refuses to go into a pair of Sheets with him. aside

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Undress I say, or I shall be most villanous angry agen.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: It must out, and it will out, but I am to be excus'd, for I have plaid my part, and counterfeited, till I am come to almost past counterfeiting. To Bed quotha', 'Slife I had as live lye in a Charnel house, I don't blame my Mistriss for loving another, but hark, I hear a rusling [noise below] 'tis certainly she, oh that I were now transform'd. aside

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Why the Devil, come you not to Bed?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.l: I am hasting as fast as I can Sir. undresses her self.
Please you to go in before, I won't stay a moment after you.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Oh the intollerable Pride, and Plague of Woman-kind! I tell ye I will not budge a foot without ye, therefore come away, I will break thee of this humour at last. pulls her in.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Oh undone! quite undone!

div.stage: Enter as below Mrs. Easy, and Lovechange.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: All is husht, and still, I hope all's well, oh my dearest Lovechange, if you did but know with what regret I leave you, your pitty, wou'd certainly augment your love. 'Tis almost day, and yet methinks 'tis but a little moment we have been together: Oh how short the hours of love and pleasure seem.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I think so too my Dear, wou'd it had pleas'd the gods to have bound us thus eternally together.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Can you dear Lovechange, speak this Language still? after enjoyment, men grow dull, and cold.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Number not me, amongst the common rout of those, whose beastly Appetite begets a short liv'd passion, mine like the object that first caus'd it, is pure, unchangable, without deceit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: I must believe you, and must love you too, but we must part, oh that ungrateful word!

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: But we must meet agen, that only hope attones for the unkindness of the other, pray don't suffer many hours to pass, before you let me see you, I shall dye with one whole day of absence.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: You please me, when you do but wish to see me, and to return that goodness, for 'tis such [sighs] Ile study how to love, and how to please, and how to keep you ever in this state â€” This bless'd Estate of loving. But this is an Argument we must discourse at large of, now Sir adieu, for the first time I think we have done well.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I cannot leave the house, till I know how you speed with your too passionate Husband.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Ile creep softly up, if he be asleep, I'me safe, for nothing but the noise of money can wake him, attend you below.

div.stage: A Bed-chamber discover'd, with Peg and Mr. Easy in't.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Discover'd! and undone!

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Betray'd! ruin'd betray'd! oh thou wicked, thou treacherous Wretch, where's my Wife, my lewd, wicked Wife?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Are you mad?
