sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: Yes, I am, and will shew it, thou Eternal Baggage.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p:
So now let him strike,
They fight, Peg puts out the Candle. Exit Peg. if he can aim well.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.p: This shan't serve your turn, I will cudgel thee, till I have not left a bit of skin on thy bones, I don't expect thou shou'dst tell me whereabouts thou art, no Huswife, Ile feel you out he gropes to find her. I will, and so feel thee, that thou shalt feel me too.

div.stage: Enter Peg softly, and Mrs. Easy, in the same night-Gown that Peg had on.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: So, now go you in, and receive a blow or two, and be sure you cry out lustily, and Ile come to your assistance with a Candle.

div.stage: To Mrs. Easy aside. Exit Peg

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Good dear Husband be'nt so passionate, what have I done to cause this?

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Thou impudent Harlot, dost call me Husband? tell me truly, confess, confess, what Rogue, has got thy Mistriss out, where is she a Catterwawling? confess, or I will dissect thee, for thou art her Pimp â€” beats her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Your grief has made you lunatick, I am your Wife, hold, hold your prophane hands.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: No, I will mark thee with a Vengeance, Ile spoil your Pimping.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Murther, murther, since you are so inhumane, I will have no mercy on your Reputation, murther!

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Bless me! what do I see, my dear Mistriss?

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Ha, ha, her dear Mistriss? 'tis so, 'tis so, I, I, thou art Peg, and this is my own sweet Wife. looks on 'um both.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Sir, pray let me know why you use me thus? Is it not enough that you have married me to an old stinking Carcass, a useless thing, but you must beat me? I will no more endure you, no not the sight of thee.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Sweet Wife, most merciful Wife, bear with the frailties of my age.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: I have born with 'em too long.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Aye, there's it, It's that sticks by thee, but dear Wife I protest, I took thee all this while for Peg.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: How came you to mistake?

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Why, when I was in bed, as you made me go before, you know, I fancy'd that the Papers which you were looking on at the Table â€”

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p:
Which was no other then a Prayer-Book to prolong time only.
To Mrs. Easy aside

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy:
sp.p: And thinking it might have been a Love-Letter (for I am naturally jealous) stole out of Bed, and looking thee full in the face, I thought thou hadst been Peg, very Peg; as I am a lover of thy vertue, I know not how I came to be mistaken, but so 'twas, and I dare swear â€”

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: What Sir, that 'twas I? Lord how merry you are Sir.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: And must I suffer, because you are old and blind?

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Truth is, 'tis very unreasonable, pardon me my fair, my Angelical Wife, I will never trust my eyes again in this case.

sp.speaker: Peg,
sp.p: Pray forsooth bear with his Weakness, and the Infirmity of Age.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p:
Ah how she aggravates my crime, old, and age were no
harm, but that she's brisk and youthful, patience, good Lady, patience.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: I'me resolv'd Ile pardon ye this once, in pitty to your years.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Aye, there 'tis agen.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: But if ever I find you faulty again, Ile be divorc'd.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Thou hast reason, for on my Consccience thou art as good a Virgin, as when I had thee.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Ile deny that, or she has past her night but ill. Aside.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: I will not bed with you to night, for besides that I am exceedingly offended with you, you have mortifi'd all inclinations of a Bedfellow in me, and so fare you well Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Patience I sayâ€” though I have no great matter to do a bed with her, yet I dare not trust her out of my sight,â€” but I must let her have her will this once, [aside] have you forgiven me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p:
I shall do by the morning perhaps.
Exit Mr. Easy. So, go thy ways, and dream, if thou hast any subject for it in thy Brain, whilst Ile to Lovechange, and in his arms, compleat the rest of this so well begun night.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I too, deserve something for acting' so judiciously in this affair.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Thou, dear Peg, art Loves Matchivil, and deserv'st a Statue rear'd to thy memory for all honest discreet Maids to worship.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Haste Madam, for Mr. Lovechange stays to take a parting kiss I'me glad we are come off so nobly, and that you have a little time, good for a little more delight, when you are pleas'd, we must contrive some way to free poor Mrs. Grace, who suffers for Loves sake too.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Let me alone for that. Exeunt ambae.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: I wonder in my heart, where this Mistriss of mine is, she'l e'n stay till 'tis light, and discover her self, pray Heavens she come before the house is up.
Oh Madam I'me glad you are come before my Master, well how thriv'd you Madam?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Just as I wisht Girl, and as we contriv'd it, he met me at the Duck-Pond side, where we stay'd most part of the night. Oh had the Joys which I receiv'd been meant to me!

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Madam you see, what imagination can do, and did he do as he ought to do Madam?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: O Clare! he said and did so many kind things to me!

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: So many say you Madam? Nay then we shall have him come home as tame, and pensive, as a Gamester, out-done in his own Trade of Nicking, now it may be I may go quietly about my business, all this day at least.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: And I may lye quietly too, unless I can cheat him agen, well I was never so pleas'd, and displeas'd in my Life before, some way I will find to be reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Some such Comical way.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: No my hopes are gone for ever having of him this way in my power, oh this treacherous man that I have so oblig'd.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: And he has this night made some returns.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Stay, when I think how great a satisfaction 'twas to him to believe himself in the Arms of Mrs. Easy I can't think of a better revenge, then to let him know it was not she.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Why, will you tell him Madam?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Yes, and at once destroy his vain glory, and let him know how sensible I am of the affront, if he has any sence of shame, or honour, this may reclaim him.
sp.stage: Enter Lovechange singing, taking no notice of his Wife.
sp.p: He's coming; how now Mr. Lovechange, what no good morrow after a whole nights absence.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: What the Devil do you up so early? you become your bed far better.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I can't rest Mr. Lovechange, when you are not there.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: You must use your self to such things, Husband and Wife, were not made to lye Eternally together.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Why, Mr. Lovechange, what other use can you put your self to a nights?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I thank ye for that I'faithâ€”Whatâ€”then to lye with my own Wife? as I take it, there were no Articles between you, and I, to leave off any part of my former Trade, as Drinking, Gamingâ€”

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: And Whoring.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Nay, my Dear, as for thatâ€”believe me, I have left it quite off. A man that has a Wife so experienc'd as thou art, so kind, so willing a Wife, faith I think he were worse then a Tyger to abuse thee, thou hast all my stock, believe me dear Soul.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Which is a very small one.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Faith a Man, that drinks, and Games, can't be very brisk that way.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Drinking was ever counted an Enemy to our Sex, but pray Sir how does gaming abuse it?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Why faith, if a Man has ill luck, as likely I have â€” What with Fretting, Swearing, Damming, and throwing, my Spirits disperse, which shou'd retire to the place you wot on.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: You think any excuse may serve for a Wife, all this, may make you unkind at home, but do the Ladies abroad find your fretting, Damming, Swearing, and throwing, disperse Nature in you?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ah! I see where the Worm bites, thou art politickly jealous of me.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Oh fye! Jealous? (that were a fault indeed) of one so kind, so just, and true a Husband as you are Mr. Lovechange.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Thou hast said all in a word, Egad I wou'd not change thee for the finest Miss in Town.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Yes, there is a certain Lady, that for a Night, you did not care, if you made an exchange with.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Who I? I defie the World.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: You have not been to Night, with the dearest, the finest Woman?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: How! 'Slife, this comes home to me. aside. Who I! I've been Drinking, and Gaming, away with these jealous Fopperies.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: You were more oblig'd to the kind shades in St. Iames's Park, than to the Moon, who's light perhaps might have discover'd your errour.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: O confound her! all's out, how came she to know it? aside

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What are you studying for an excuse? a lye to put me off with?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I will out-face her. aside Now art thou as mad, as blind Love and Jealousie can make thee, prithee to Bed and settle thy Brain, goâ€”

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Mr. Lovechange, I have no other end in this, more then to let you know your errour, and that I am sensible of the indignity, take notice I knew of your meeting at the Duck-Pond side, and shall reward your kindness. She offers to go out.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Duck-Pond side? Stay, I grow serious, that I have infinite obligations to thee, I must ever own, and I had nothing to return you back, but this bare substance, and a gratitude, and what the heats of youth may prompt me too I can't tell; But when you ask me truly what they are I will inform your knowledge, and what you charge me with of this nights action, believe me Madam, is false information, I saw no woman, by the Duck-Pond side.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: How can I credit this? and yet I shou'd believe him, aside perhaps my eyes inform'd me of your falshood, I am not apt to credit evil Tongues.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Oh don't pursue an errour, to my prejudice; upon my Honour; by all the vows of sacred Love, and Marriage, I was not near that place, but something I remember past last night, 'twixt whom I know not, that perhaps deceiv'd you. Ile search it out and satisfie your Jealousie.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Oh Heavens! if this be true what thing am I? aside

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Come don't vex thy self with peevishness, don't create these ills, that will torment thee. Ile satisfie thy doubt, believe me Dear.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p:
Oh I am ruin'd, [aside] if he be not false, how hard a fate is mineâ€” Ile take your word Sir.
Exit Lovechange

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: For Heavens sake, Madam keep your courage up, for if you have Cuckold my Master by â€” mistake, 'tis the best way to put as good a face on't, as you can, there's no recalling it. Lord what a business you make of a thing that is not worth speaking of.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: But guilt's a strange thing Clare.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Why you don't believe him sure, can all your sences fail you, or will you credit him, in spight of 'em all, you saw, you heard, and felt too, as you say.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: They were all prepar'd to receive him, without any other imagination, and might be easily deceiv'd.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: But since there's no possibility of any other Person's coming then his, you ought not to give your faith so easily. But Madam, here comes Mr. Courtwell, who will perhaps discover more.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Shame, and Confusion, will not let me hear him.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p:
Now, wou'd I give the world to know this Womans name, and abode, these curiosities, don't usually last after enjoyment, one wou'd have thought I had glutted my self of Woman-kind for these two days, and of her for ever, but 'twas a sweet plump active Rogue. 'Slife, yonder's the Rogue Love-change,
Enter Lovechange pensive.
he looks like a defeated Lover â€” But what the Devil makes him here at the Widdows, well a rich Widdow is the very sink of younger Brothers, and harbours more then a Gaming house, I don't like his being here though, it looks like Rivalship, and though it be but Justice in him, yet I can by no means permit itâ–ª It makes me angryâ€”Why how now Lovechange, methinks thou look'st melancholly upon't, what no hope from the Widdow? for I perceive you Rival me.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Oh trouble not your head with the Widdow, you may remember I told ye she was not for your turn.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Are you sure of that?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Most certain.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: And are you the Man, the happy Man.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Why, what exceptions have you against me, what, Ile warrant, you thought the noise of Lands, and Joynctures wou'd have carried it, but know Will, that Wit, and Parts are greater Motives.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: And does your conceit Edward! perswade you to the belief, that you are so qualify'd?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Faith, I never studied that, but the Ladies are kind, and do tell me of some such charms I am Master of.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: The Lady too Ned, that you met in the Park, she has that goodness for you too, hah!

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: She is satisfy'd, and that's sufficient.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I hope she was, for I did my best. Lord Ned, that thou shou'd'st be so simple, to believe thy self Master of all hearts. All the Ladies submit to you dear Ned, so did the Lady in the Mall, did she not; But there was a Man, (though not so considerable as you Sir) that pleas'd her better by the Duck-Pond side, and perhaps may make as good an interest in her, as you have in the Widdows heart, you guess the Man, and so farewel Ned, farewel, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Prithee stay, Egad thou art pleasant company my dear Soul; and was there say you? was there such a spark? that did the feat so well at the Duck-Pond side? ha, ha, ha?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I am glad you are so merry Sir.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Faith, I can't forbear being infinitely pleas'd to find my friend so happy, I am glad I know this secret, I might have wanted the means to have convinc'd my Wife else, that 'twas not I, but I wonder who the Devil the Lady shou'd be, surely some one taken with my Person, and that had a certain longing â€” and how Will, and how did you find her? for I am willing to communicate my blessings.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Why hadst thou ever injoy'd her?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: In truth not, nor never will for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: You seem'd yesterday to praise her to the Skies, and is she faln so low in your opinion.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: She that I spoke of, was, and is the same, and nothing but Age, can alter her from being the finest, sweetest Person in the World.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I found her so, (aside) and in her arts of Love, so ravishingâ€”

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: And was she brisk that way, say you? Will.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: To a miracle, I can't contain my joy, I must discover allâ€” and now dear Lovechange if thou wou'dst let me know her name, and quality?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: By my troth Sir, if I cou'd serve you this way, you might command me; But you are already happy enough, be not too glorious with it.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: What humour's this, I can't understand him, but Clare must be my guideâ€” Your Servant Sir, since you are so fantastique.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p:
Your Servant dear Will, ha, ha.
Exit Lovechange.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I cannot comprehend this Fellow's fancy, now I am for the Widdow, whom I must gain in spight of all her peevishness, I know she has no a version to my Person, and though I don't love her much, yet, my Pride obliges me to come off Conquerour, but oh this other lovely, kind, obliging Stranger.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Oh excess of Treachery!

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Who's here, ere another Rival? Pox on 'em, how they swarm about a rich Widdow, 'Slife, I think he's dressing himself.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Sure Courtwell loves this Lady, for methinks he is very active, how shall I accost him, how as a stranger shall I begin a discourse to him? Ile pretend I am his Rival. aside

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Your Servant Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Yours Sir, proceed if you have ought with me?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: You look and talk Sir, as if you were Major Domo.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: It may be Sir I am, will that afflict you?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: My name is Courtwell Sir, and I pretend to the Lady of this Mansion.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Very likely! but whether she will fall to your share or not, is a great question.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Not to be made by a School-boy, pretty Lad, hast any nickers, or cherry-stones? if thou hast, there be Children of thy own size without, will hold thee play.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Oh Sir, Ile give you leave to be witty with my youth, whilst I laugh at your gravity, and wisdom. In short Sir, if the Lady likes the Boy, better then your Manhood, you'l find cold entertainment, go Sir, take this answer, she is not for your turn, go Sir, you loose your time, there is a certain kind, obliging Lady.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Oh the Devil have they that story by the end too? Well this Clare has betraid me, however this little diminutive Man, sha'not affront me, yet hang't he's a child not worth my malice.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Hold Sir, you pass no further this way, that leads you to the door.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Prit hee unhand me youth, thou'lt make me angry, and then I were too blame, with so much innocence.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: None of your put off's Sir, I am not so young, nor innocent, as you take me to be; I can do many things that wou'd proclaim me Man, don't upbraid the smoothness of my Chin, my Sword's as rough as thine, and I dare draw it.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Very pretty. Lord how it tattles, why little talking Monsieur, by what authority do you resist me? can that fair Face disguise it self in anger? and that's the most that thou canst do, let's see thee frown, that perhaps wou'd break a Ladies heart, a soft, young silly Lady, but I make sport at theee, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: What shall I do, to raise his anger up? For I had rather that way meet my Death, then see him in the embraces of another: That will but kill me a more cruel way. [aside] Come Sir, though you are pleas'd, I can be angry, you shall find the effects on't, but this is no place to decide the business in, Ile meet you in the Park, a pass, or two will end the fatal difference.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Sure he has some other motive then the love of the Widdow, that carries him to this rashness, the Boy grows angry, serious, and can fight perhaps. aside

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: No consideration Sir, if you refuse to fight me, I will Pistol ye, take your choice to live with Honour, or to dye with Infamy.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Well Sir, Ile meet you there, but don't care for fighting with thee much.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I have Conditions too for Peace, as well as War, and love fighting, as little as you, I'me glad he consents to go out o'th house, I don't care to have my story known to any but himself, who onely can relieve me.

div.trailer: The End of the third Act.

div.head: Actus Quartus,

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: OH dear Madam, what shall we do for Mrs. Grace, I vow she is in the lamentablest taking, nay, and a worse matter then that, my old Master is resolv'd to fright her out of her wits, till she consent to marry Sir Ralph.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Why I thought he had by mistake married Betty.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: So he did Madam, but they design to put her off for a peice of money, it being a cheat, and without a License, and Betty offers for a thousand pound to sit down with the loss, and release him to Mrs. Grace, but all this does not satisfie, for Mrs. Grace is refractory, and will by no means consent.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Poor Grace, what contrivance shall we think of, to release her from her bondage and torment.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Alas Madam, if that were the worst, but her Uncle designs this morning to let out some of her hot blood, as he calls it, he has sent for a Surgeon, and pretending she is mad, means to try conclusions by opening a vein, or two.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: He dares not be so cruel, and inhumane.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I suppose he dares not design so ill a thing indeed, but she being very young, and innocent, will soon (at least he thinks so) be brought to yeild to any thing, rather then be so us'd, but Madam I have thought of a stratagem; when my Master sends out for a Surgeon, Ile let you see my wit, I will not tell you before hand.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Thou art so excellent at contrivance, that I will not question the success, nor ask thee what it is, go on and prosper; but call upon me by and by for a Letter, that I intend to write to Lovechange.

div.head: Scene Second, Chairs set out.
div.stage: Enter Mr. Easy, Grace, Betty, and Sir Ralph.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: This, is your place of execution, consider, repent, and be sav'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: I, I, Mrs. Grace, that's your safest way, tis very ill lying in a cold grave this Winter time, a Bed, and a good Bed fellow were much better, consider, consider, I vow my heart bleeds to think how you will suffer for love of me.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: What shall I do Betty, is their no way left for my deliverance?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Do not fear it Madam, Peg, and I, have laid our heads together for your relief, however make all the signs of fear you can. aside

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: I know not what can relieve me, but I will hope well, good Uncle, what i'st you'd have me do? how can I marry with a man that is already married?

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Aye, by your contrivance Baggage he is, but thou shalt suffer severely for't, and this Slut I will make dance a new Galliard in Bridewell.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Truly Sir I don't fear you, but for my poor Mistriss sake I wou'd do any thing but loose my Husband.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Oh! I had rather hear a Schreech-Owl then that voice, Husband quotha'? I defie thee.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Why Sir, I have youth and beauty enough to be a Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Why I tell thee I care not, and thou wer't the Devil, so thou hadst money, oh I am distracted to think that I shou'd loose six thousand pound, and Mrs. Grace.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: You hear Sir, there's all his grief to loose the money.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: I like him the better for't, â€” Well you will beg pardon and be receiv'd to mercy?

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: First Sir, let me see Sir Ralph free from Betty, for I confess I wou'd not marry a man that shou'd be in danger of the Gallows.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p:
Oh how I tremble at that word, I, I, pray good Uncle, let me be freed from this little Jilt here, and then I do not fear my fate as they say with Mrs. Grace, nay if thou dost not release me I will
give thee no money, nor no consolation, thou shalt 'en live by thy wits, and thou wilt for Ralph.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I am well enough satisfy'd to part upon good consideration.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: What be they, what be they, any Condition.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Only giving me a thousand pound Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: How! a thousand pound? Mercy upon us!

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I cannot live by my Wits, and thereforeâ€”

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Thou wilt ruine me, a thousand pound?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: You will loose six by the bargain Sir, in loosing my Mistriss.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: That's well consider'd I confess; But will nothing less, then that mighty sum suffice you.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: By no means, for Sir I must marry, I wou'd not fall much lower then a Lady Ship.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: O insatiable Woman! a thousand pound! why pray Mrs. Betty be good and merciful.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I have said, and will hold there Sir, or keep my Title.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: I am not able to endure the thoughts of parting with so much money â€”

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Come Sir Ralph, since there's no other way, you know Mr. Lovechange owes you a thousand pound, give her that Bond, and it shall be sufficient.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I am content to take it Sir, but will Mr. Lovechange pay me, is it a good debt?

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Ile secure it good, here, here's the Bond, take it â€” and with it my curse. cryes Here's an after-clap indeed, had I had any thing for my Money, it wou'd not have griev'd me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Come Sir, it can't be hope, this 'tis to have to do with any of their Sex. But here's Grace to make you amends with, take her.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Hold Sir, two words to that bargain.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Refractory still! I will shew no mercy on thee, Sir Ralph keep her here, whilst I see if the Surgeon been't come that I sent for?

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Sweet Mrs. Grace consent without compulsion as they say, for I protest but that I have given a thousand pounds towards thee, I wou'd rather give you over, then see you suffer any hurt for me, therefore pray be civil a little, though it be against your inclinations to be so.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: I shall not consent.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Easy, and Amorous, drest as a Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Here Sir, here's your Patient, and though she looks so soberly at present, she's stark mad poor Soul. cryes. And because of her Quality, I am loath to have her to Bedlam, if any Cure may be had otherwise.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Sir forbear, I am not mad, nor will be so unless you make me. Amorous holds her, and feels her Pulse.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Alas good Lady, you be troubled wit de Love, wit de vere great extravagance, you be very much distemper'.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: You be very much de Coxcomb Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy:
sp.p: Aye, now she begins, come, come, to bleeding of her, is not that very good?

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: We', we', ver' necessar, come Lady.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Thou inhumane fellow, think'st thou indeed I'me distemper'd, and need thy cure, or if I were so, that thou hast any skill? Yet once you sed that Love was my Disease, and that indeed was truth. weeps

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Vat Complexion be de Man of dat you love, and dat can be cruel to so very amiable a Person.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: He is not cruel, but my Uncle is, and with your help designs to kill me sure, do so, for since I cannot marry Amorous I do desire to dye. weeps.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: See Sir, how her fit alters, she'l laugh agen anon, I pray Sir be speedy.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p:
I am not able to see her blood, and therefore must withdraw.
Exit Sir Ralph.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Come Madamosel, you must permit me to do someting to cure your amours, let me see, she must be ty'd to dis Chey'r, let me try it first. sits down Dis is not very convenient Sir, 'tis too hard, and metinks too litel.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Tis well, 'tis well Sir, pray to your business.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p:
No indeed Sir, 'tis not good, make you de experiment pray, and see if 'tis convenient.
Old Easy sits down.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p:
Cocks bodikins, these villanous Outlandish-Men make such a pudder, an English Man wou'd have kill'd you half a score, whilst you cure one.
Offers to rise, Amorous holds him down.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Help to bind him fast Boy. They bind him in the Chair.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: What d'ye mean Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Only to tye you up to your good Behaviour a little.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Oh happy deliverance! Amorous is it you?

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p:
Yes, and do you shift for your self, and leave me to handle him.
Exit Grace,

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Villains, unhand me, oh thou Monster Amorous, is it thou?

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Even I Sir, I am turn'd Surgeon to serve you Sir, come strip up his Arms, and let us bleed him speedily. I have a drench here that must be given first, 'twil make him bleed like one of twenty. Pours down something.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Oh I am kill'd, I am murther'd.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: No, you are not to dye so patiently.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Yes, I will dye on purpose that thou may'st be hang'd: no help near? Wife, Grace, Betty, Murther, murther!

div.stage: Enter Sir Ralph, Jo, and other Servants.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Ah Pox of his bauling, I must shift for my self now.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Oh are you caught Sir, I shall handle you now, 'tis the Rogue Amorous.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Amorous, how came he in?

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: How shall he get out, oh the Devil â€”

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Have I got ye i'faith into my Clutches? Dear Uncle, leave his punishment to me, I have a Servant here that has the notablest Hed-piece for Villany that ever was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Do any thing to him, that may torment him soundly, have no mercy on him, sweet Sir Ralph.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: I warrant ye Uncle, I have a brave place to put him into, and will have him bastinado'd thrice a day for Recreation, till I have mortify'd his Love.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Fool, I do despise, and dare thy worst of evils, were Grace but safe, oh I shou'd be content to suffer, I'me sure they dare not murther me.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Yes Grace shall be safe, and my Wife within this hour; thou shalt never see her face more.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Devil do thy worst!

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Here Io, take him into thy Custody, let him be put into the Vault, let silence and darkness be his Companions.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Come Sir, along with me Sir, I shall teach you the art of Surgery.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Nay, if thou escap'st now, Ile say thou had'st a Witch to thy Mother, and a Devil to thy Father. Exeunt severally

div.stage: Enter Courtwell and Perigreen from fighting, Perigreen wounded â–ª

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Rash Boy! to force me to this rudeness, for 'twas not manhood in me thus to hurt thee, alas, thou cou'dst not fight, thou hadst no skill to hold thy weapon for thy own advantage.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Sir you have done enough if it be home.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Sure thou art some poor dispairing thing that seek'st a Death from any hand, why did'st thou chuse out mine, for that base action, there are a thousand Murtherers, Ruffins, things desperate as thy self, that wou'd have done this, with the least provocation, why didst thou chuse a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Thou a Gentleman? cou'd any thing, that is not basely born, commit such villanies as thou hast done, ere since thou call'dst thy self a Man?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Come don't talk, but let me lead thee to a Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Mr. Perigreen and Courtwell say you? how in the name of wonder shou'd they come to fall out?

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Nay, I know not Madam, but I believe 'twas about you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Me? But see Clare where they areâ€”

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Curse on her for coming now, a little time might have discover'd all.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I'me glad she has releas'd me.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I heard of some difference between you, and thought it but Justice to prevent further danger.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Twas well, and charitably perform'd, Widdow, but I suppose 'twas care of your new Gallant here that hastned you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Oh villanous Courtwell! what hast thou done! the poor youth bleedsâ€” alas, Sir, lets haste for some relief?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Widdow I have a word with you, before you go.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p:
I have nothing to say to you, forbear.
Exeunt Clare and Perigreen.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: But I must stay you for a small season to tell you Widdow you are a â€”

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What thou Impertinent?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: A strange inconstant, faithless, amorous thing, whom I have now thrown from my heart.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Have you so Sir?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Yes, and to make thee wretched, know I love elsewhere?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Yes Sir, your new Lady perhaps, which you met last night in the Mall.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: How! I did not think thou hadst been arriv'd to the years of Witchcraft yet, Widdow?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: There needs none to know your secrets Sir, one need but have the faculty of hearing well, to know 'em all, for you are loud enough in the Proclamation of'em.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Now are all my hopes dasht here, this must be Clare, or Lovechange, the last I believe, purposely to ruine all my expectations with the Widdow, that Rascal I must sight [aside] truth is I did meet a Lady in the Mall, a fine handsome airy Rogue.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: And was she kind too?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Wondrous kind, nay of her self, so wittily found out the place of entertainment, and made the treat too, when she came there.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: How Sir! were you in any House?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: House? no, we enjoy'd our selves like the gods of old, in Groves, and Gloomy shades, on Rivers Banks, faith Widdow, to kill thee quite, I met a Lady on the Duck-Pond side, that would have fir'd an Anchoret:

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: How Sir? by the Duck-Pond side, thou'lt kill me indeed, if thou undeceiv'st me not presently? aside

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Even thereâ€” since Lovechange, has told her Ile do his business for him. aside I must confess the blessing was not design'd for me, but Lovechange, I drest my self as like as possible, â€” and took all she said to him, on my self.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Oh I am ruin'd! and was she easily won Sir? for perhaps I know the Lady â€” Oh how curious I am to know my own dishonour. [aside]

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I do suppose Lovechange had prepar'd her, for to me she made but weak resistance, she said 'twas well the darkness hid her blushes, and that the Bench was a very undecent place.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: My very words! Oh I cou'd kill the Rascal! what different passions is my Soul possest with! (aside) Courtwell, thou art a Villain, this Lady I know, and thou hast abus'd her honour, not won her heart, and all the rest was but a Rape, a base unworthy Rape, and one perhaps that shall be reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p:
By this light the Widdow loves me, I know it by her Jealousie, perhaps this may be the critical minute, Ile follow her and try my chance: Perhaps too I may learn something from this young Bully that may explain this Riddle to me.
Exit Courtwell.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: How shall I contrive to see my dear Mistress? For I am not able to live without her, though I am a damn'd mad fellow, and love all her Sex in generall, yet in her is bounded all my love and pleasureâ€”Pox on't, I am damn'd dull at Invention.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: What melancholly after his Gaming? Well I hope I may trust my self alone with him to day, therefore Ile venture in. aside What Sir, in a doleful dump? what wou'd you give to be put out on't now.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Prithee good property of my Wife, leave me.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Faith Sir, I wou'd have a word or two in private with you first

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Pox on't, thou wou'dst not be so forward if I desir'd thy Company now.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: What will you say now, and Ile tell you what you are thinking on.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Not of your late cruelty to me Clare! nor care I a farthing if you are come to offer me, what you then deny'd me, and therefore leave me.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Faith Sir, I have not the heart to obey you till I have left you in better humour, come Sir!

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: If I shou'd trust a secret with thee Clare, thou wou'd be blabbing it to my Wife.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: You can trust me with nothing but what I know already Sir!

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Faith 'tis not unlikely!

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: I am acquainted Sir, with all your last nights Intrigue.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: The Devil thou artâ€” and like a wicked Jade, thou hast inform'd my Wife.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: And is that the cause of your affliction?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: That's all, that's all, but Clare was it kindly done to turn a base Informer here at home, just thus it had been hadst thou been kind to me, on my Conscience, thou wou'dst have told thy Mistress on't.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: I hope you don't think me so simple Sir.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Thou never consider'st the evil consequences Clare, of carrying Tales? now must my daily allowance be shortned, now must I drudge at home, for the expences of my Whoring abroad, nay and perhaps be chain'd up like a Mastiff dog all day, to make me more fierce a nights: well Clare, if I am forc'd to keep home for want of stock, and kept fasting, the whole force of my hungry love will fall most heavily on thee, and I will shew thee no more mercy, then thou hast done to me.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: I don't fear you Sir, since you were with so fine a Lady last night.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I am found out, they know my Roguery, and have mistook the place only but that's enough to ruine me. (aside) But Clareâ€”Is there no hopes of a forgiveness? no making up of this breach? Methinks you shou'd follow the greatest examples, that forgive all faults confest with penitence, I must confess, I had a Lady, Clare.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Oh, wicked Man! how stifly he deny'd this to my Lady to day! Well Sir, what will you give me to absolve this sin, and restore you to my Mistresses grace agen?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Give thee? Why my heart, thou shalt command me.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Why then Sir, 'twas even my Mistress, and your own Wife that met you at the Duck-Pond side:

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: What? the Duck-Pond side?

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: I Sir, and in St. Iames's Park, where you were kinder to her, than ever you were before.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ouns! my Wife?

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Yes, your Wife, don't disturb your self, 'twas but one nights loss to you, and that sure you may afford for all she has done for youâ–ª saith Sir, we knew of your Intrigue, and were resolv'd to counterplot ye, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Devil! why dost laugh?

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: To think how safe you fancy'd your self to be in the Arms of Mrs. Easy.

sp.speaker: Lov
sp.p: Oh Curse! I am miserable both ways, not only to find my self Cuckolded by Courtwell (aside) but to have this discovery of my love made to my dear Easy.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: What, are you disorder'd still? Troth, I think you may be glad to make your peace on an any terms.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p:
One comfort I have yet left, I'me releas'd from the slavery of my Wife by knowing I am a Cuckold, and that shall secure the credit too of my dear Mistriss whose Honour's now in danger, this secret too, 'tis fit I find some way to let her know, and consult how to prevent a further growth, and thou Courtwell shalt feel the effects of my displeasure.
Exit Lovechange.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: O Lord, what have I done! he talks as if it were not he that met my Mistress, but Courtwell, I am quite undone. 'Tis so by my Maiden-head, if I cou'd be serious now; I cou'd cry, and fret my self into a Consumption, for this unlucky mistake of mine, which I dare not discover to my Lady neither, she has vexation enough already without this addition, oh that I cou'd bring all about agen?

div.stage: Mr. Easy's house, Enter Sir Ralph and Jo.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Oh Sir! I have excellent news for you, the lost sheep is found, I have taken your Mistriss Sir, just as she was marching off with all her Moveables, her Jewels, and other Toys, and Sir I have her fast â€”

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: In a certain convenient dark Lodging, which her Uncle provided for her, where she shall fast and pray, till her stomach come down to marry you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Aye Io, wou'd I had her? that is her money, for she is very beautiful that way. Io, but heark ye I wou'd fain see her, I know her mind, for 'tis a pretty little Rogue.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p:
Sir, I can do you that favour, for her Uncle has committed the Key to my charge, with a command that none but you shall see her.
Exit Jo.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: So Mrs. Grace, what is your stomach come down or not?

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: No, nor never will to thee, had you lov'd me, you cou'd not have suffer'd me to be us'd thus for your sake, a Gentleman wou'd have desisted, after so much aversion as I have shown you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Pshaw, whaw, tell not me of desisting, nor aversions as I have shown ye. Mrs. Grace, you are a Fool, and don't know so well as your Uncle and I, what's good for you, I have two thousand pound a year mun, and I am a Knight, and all that mun, keep my Gilt Coach, and five livery men â€” and Amorous has scarce a shilling for a dirty Hack.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: My Master speaks reason to you Lady.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Your Master and you, are a couple of sots, impertinent Fools, I hate ye both, and wou'd not marry him, though I shou'd perish there, whence you draw me now, Tis Paradice compar'd to where thou art.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Oh Rare! oh rich! what, you can rant, and scold, one wou'd have thought I vow that Butter wou'd not a melted in her mouth.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: You'l make me rave, you will, and I will Rave too, you can't tye my tongue up, that's still free to curse you with.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Toes, here's fine doings.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Io, carry her down, she may be tame e're night.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Do what thou wilt, thou shalt never bring me to be tame enough for thee: this dark, this solitary Cave best suits my absent Love, here I contemplate, here my thoughts are free, and like a little Bird Ile sit, and sing a melancholly note within my little Cave.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p:
I, do what you will, we shall change your note, fear it not.
Exit Sir Ralph.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p:
So, now you are fast agen, well I am a cruel Rogue, for all this though, that can find no remorse.
Enter Amorous

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: How now Goaler, what black deed are you a doing there?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Only a puting your Mistress into her hole Sir.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: My Mistress there, thou art not so barbarous?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Indeed I am Sir.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p:
Was it for this your kindness brought me out, and chang'd
my Lodging for this opener place to bury her in, Dog, set her loose or by the sacred passion I have for that fair Maid Ile strangle thee.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Say you so Sir, you had better let me alone though, heark Sir, she's well contented with her retirement. Grace sings below.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Oh charming Virgin, how thy innocence can make thy entertainment, sirrah deliver the Key, or thou'rt dead.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Stand off Sir, I have a rusty Sword, and you have no weapon, stand off, orâ€”

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Slave dost dare me?â€”. Runs into him, takes away his Sword, and wounds him.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Oh I am dead, I am dead! stark stone dead.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: 'Slife I think the Rogue speaks truth, he's dead indeed, but if he be Ile justifie the action, stay, what am I next to do? In passing out perhaps I may be seen â€” I have devis'd a way for my escape, but first Ile release my fair Prisoner. Vnlocks the Vault, and enters.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Now if I durst stir, I wou'd get away and shew e'm such a trickâ€” but heark they are ascending, and I must lye purdue. lyes down again.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: My Dearest! 'tis no time to express joy in, this fellow I fear is dead, and we have both need of a safe retreat, here's the Key of the Gate to the Feilds, get you out, and go the back way to my Aunts, 'tis but six doors off, you know she'l receive you well, whilst I escape another way.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p:
My dearest Amorous, take care of what I love, and let me see thee quickly releast from this base Mansion, where naught but terrour dwells.
Exit Grace.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p:
Come Sir, I have a word or two with you in the next room, Ile put on this Rogue's disguise, and that will be a means for my escape.
Exit Amorous dragging out Jo by the heels Enter Mrs. Easy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p:
This Wench stays very long, I hope she has found my dear Lovechange.
Enter Mr. Easy, peeping after his Wife.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p:
My heart tells me there is something a forging, but what I know not, perhaps I may know more.
Enter Peg not seeing Easy

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Madam, here's the answer to your Letter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p:
How! a Letter to my Wife? gently, good supporters, gently.
As Peg and Mrs. Easy stands to read the Letter, he steals behind them & with his Spectacles reads over their shoulders

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Why didst thou stay so long? It grows late, and I am impatient to be gone to Lovechange.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: O rare! is it thereabouts with you? aside

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: I vow Madam, he kept me there so long â€” asking me questions about you, kissing your dear Letter, and sending so many recommendations to you, and so many curses to my old Master.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Fine, delicate young Bawd. aside

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: I had rather he shou'd wish him well Peg. That's in Heaven.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Hum, hum, charitable, kind Wife. aside

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: But to my Letter, dear Lovechange let me kiss thee, before I read thee. kisses the Letter, and reads.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Excellent! Aside

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Alas Peg, we are all undone, Lovechange can't meet me at Mrs. Woodbee's to night, for reasons he will tell me anon; but how anon dear Peg, and where? for I am not able to live this night without him.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: That too, I have to tell you by word of mouth.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: O horrid impudence! aside Are you not so Mistriss, nay never stare, 'tis I, even I, the poor old Cuckold, that you wish so well too.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: O sad! What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: No evasions, no lyes shall serve you, come I will lock thee up from all humane society, and have no mercy on thee.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Dear Husband!

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Dear Devil! For such, and so severe Ile be unto thee.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p:
Now all the Plot's spoil'd, this will go hard with my poor Mistriss, Ile try my Wit once more for her deliverance, for I wou'd not have her disappoint Mr. Lovechange's expectations, she must meet him to night.
Exit Peg,

div.stage: Enter Sir Ralph, and two Fellows with Battoons.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Come Brothers of the Battoon, open that door, for there's the subject of your mirth, oh how we will swinge the Rascal, and do you hear Bulleys, you must be sure you beat him, till he resign (before you that are my Witnesses) Mrs. Grace to me.

sp.speaker: 1 Fel.
sp.p:
I warrant you Sir,
They draw aside the Curtain and discover Jo sitting in a chair, drest in Amorous his cloaths.
for your business done.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Sure 'tis the Rascal Amorous return'd to make me sure, therefore to my counterfeiting. aside sits still.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: There he sits, Gentlemen to your business.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: 'Tis so, there's no resistance to be made.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: But first let me take him into examination, come sirrah answer me precisely to these particulars, first how long have you commenc'd Doctor of Divinity (for all is out) how came you to marry me to Mrs. Betty? a pox of your sanctify'd cause, 'thas cost me a thousand pounds good English Money.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: 'Tis Sir Ralph my Master. aside

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: No reply sirrah, next you quitted the long Robe, and transform'd your self to a French Doctor, a plague of your Physick, as my Uncle may say. And lastly, sirrah you wou'd have cheated me of Mrs. Grace, for which three enormities I will chastise thee most abundantly. They beat him

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Hold Sir, what do you mean Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Bind him fast Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: I am not Amorous Sir, a pox of my Vizor, I can't get it off.

sp.speaker: Sir R.
sp.p: Stop his mouth Gentlemen, for so he serv'd my Nuncle Easy.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: I am not Amorous Sir, but, butâ€”

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Stop his mouth I say, have no mercy on him, so now bastinado him soundly. They beat him, he cryes out the while.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Murther, murther, I am dead, and you shall all be hang'd.

div.stage: Overturns the Chair and falls down.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Oh Gentlemen he's dead indeed, what shall we do now?

sp.speaker: 2 Fel.
sp.p: We care not Sir, if he be dead, we shan't be hang'd for him, 'tis only you shall suffer, who set us on:

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Here be rare Rogues, no life? no he's gone, quite gone! oh what shall I do? a pox of Mrs. Grace, and all her Race, accurst I may say.

sp.speaker: 1 Fel.
sp.p: Farewel Sir, we'l shift for our selves. Exit Rogues.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.l: Ile go hide my self somewhere from the hands of Justice.
Ah Grace, 'tis thou'rt the cause of all my dolour,
But how shall I escape the Hempen Collar. Exit.

div.trailer: The End of the fourth Act.

div.head: Scena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Peg running, after her Sir Ralph.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: SWeet Mrs. Margaret don't flye me, I protest Ile do you no harm, alas I'me in distress, and only beg thy assistance.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: What's the matter Sir Ralph?

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Oh I have committed, I dare not tell thee allâ–ª

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: What, Adultery? or Fornication Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Neither, but a worse matter by much, I have kil'd Mrâ–ª Amorous, and desire you to conceal me a little, I dare not tell my Uncle? cryes

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Amorous I'me sure is safe enough, and so is Gracy, what can this fool mean? But I will now make use of him: well though I say it, I am full of device and contrivance: aside This accident Sir Ralph is very unlucky, but if you will take my advice Ile secure you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Oh any thing dear Mrs. Margaret.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: And can you keep counsel too?

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Yes sure, where my life depends on't?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: You must then beg leave of my Master, to make a visit to my Mistriss, she is kept a close Prisoner in her Chamber upon some Jealousie that's come into his Noddle, I know you may be admitted.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: And what then?

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: Oh let me alone then to work for your safety; do this presently, and before the news of your killing Amorous arrive to his Ear.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: I, I, Ile follow your counsel. cryes

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: There must be something in't, where is the body of this dead Man?

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p:
In the appartment of the Garden, but pray say nothing and here's something to close thy mouth.
Exit Sir Ralph.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p:
So, I hope this Plot will take, I must next invent a way to let my Mistress know my design, and since I am not permitted to see her, Ile write by this Fop.
Exit Peg.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What strange misfortune rules the fate of things, the first Revenge that ever I design'd, that it should so unhappily fall on my own head, 'tis too certain that I did meet Courtwell instead of my Husband: And 'tis as certain that he took me for Mrs. Easy, when I consider my condition, I find it every way so deplorable that without some extraordinary change, I shall grow weary of my Life, I am mad, and know not whom to be reveng'd on.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p:
Faith Madam, carry on the Intrigue, and let's make a perfect Plot on't?
Enter Lovechange Here comes a principal Engineer in the work.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I can't meet this Rascal Courtwell, for though I don't love this foolish Woman, whose jealousie has made me a Cuckold: Yet i'me in honour bound to fight the Villain, 'twas happy as it prov'd, that 'twas not my dear Mistriss, yet either way he merits my chastisement. aside

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Oh what shall I do? I have not power to withdraw. aside

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: All this is my Roguery. aside

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Good Evening to you Madam.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Why this distance Lovechange?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Why these Tears?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: For your unkindness Sir.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: 'Tis rather Madam, for your own lewdness, come I will not entertain you with the circumstances, but to the business, I will part with you, you know the entertainment which you gave young Courtwell on the River-side i'th Park, I know it too, and wou'd have kil'd you for the deed, but that I know the offence ought to be charg'd on your curiosity, you thought to have met me there.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Tis true, and will you punish so severely a fault of Love, alas, I meant no harm.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Twas harm to be so curious, to be jealous, and harm to think of cheating me, for so t'had been if I had met you there instead of Mrs. Easy, for I find you knew the design.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: And are not you as guilty Sir, as I?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: No, 'tis the scandal makes the sin, and not the action, custome makes it sin to us; when you offend, I bear the dishonour on't, when I, you but the little griefs. In fine, Madam I am resolv'd to part, none knows, as yet, that we are married, and if you please it may be still conceal'd.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I've nothing Sir to answer for my self, and since I can't have your heart, I am content to quit your Person too, you know the Articles between us Sir, when I married you, I made you Master of half my Fortune, take it, and what remains I will enjoy my self with, give me your handâ€” Farewel, I've had an ill bargain of thee, for a poor Months service, thou hast cost me ten thousand pounds.
sp.l: Well Clare, in this divorce some ease I find,

Since I am free, to Courtwell Ile be kind.
Exeunt Clare and Wood.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p:
So, I have shook thee off, and with very little remorse too Egadâ€” Thou wer't a good Woman, but thou'rt goneâ€” hang sorrowâ€” Ile to my sweet, pretty, little, dear Mrs. Easy, and if she can but contrive to do as much for her Husband, as i've done for my Wife, we'le 'en strike up a match A-la-mode.
Exit Lovechange.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Easy drest in Sir Ralph's cloaths, and Peg with her.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: So, so, thus far it has succeeded well.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: I wou'd thou cou'dst but see the Knight drest in my Night-gown, and Linnen, 'tis a sight worth the laughing at, i've charg'd him to sit very pensive, and dark, and to answer for me to every question ask't, if my Husband shou'd come to catechise him.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p:
'Twou'd be a Dialogue worth the hearkning too, he knowing nothing of your affairsâ€” Tis like his answers must be very proper to the questions.
Enter Mr. Easy.
Uds life Madam, here's my Master, what shall we do?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Let me alone with him, 'tis pretty dark he can't well distinguish me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Sir Ralph, when you askt me leave to give a visit to my Wife, I did not desire the doors shou'd have been shut upon you, I hearkned, and must tell you, I believe you were no better then you shou'd be.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Truth is Sir, since you have found us out, I only pretended to Mrs. Grace, but your Wife was my main design.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: How! Why thou impudent Varlet, oh horrible? dar'st thou make me a Cuckold? and tell me so? sirrah I know thou art a Coward, and I will beat thee, yes I dare venture on thee. Draws

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Nay, then 'tis time to shew a fair pair of heels, farewel Sir, Ile leave your house. runs out.

sp.speaker: Mr. E.
sp.p: I will not let thee go so, if I have any daring in me. runs after.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.p: 'S â€¢ ife I know she cannot fight, Ile after her, and see to call some body to her assistance. runs out.

div.stage: Enter Lovechange as in a street.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I see no light in my Mistresses Chamber, I wonder where they are all, and that Peg brings me no answer.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Lovechange, dear, assist me!

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p:
What the Devil art thou?
Enter old Easy, and Peg.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Oh thou Traytor to my house, have I trusted thee to this end, to rob me of my Wife and Honour?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: So, I have made fine workâ€”

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Stay Sir, don't hurt him, for who e're he be, if he have wrong'd your Wife, I will revenge it, thy Arm's too weak for such a glorious deed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Hey day! another Rival! oh I begin to see I am a most notorious Monster, I dare not encounter him though, but for thee thou villanous Sir Ralph.â€”

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Sir Ralph my Rival! â€” go Sir withdraw, this is not work for you, leave me to be your Champion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p:
Yes, yes, against my will I doâ€”but I will home and claw my Wife, my fine whorish Wife, away for this.
Exit Easy

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Now Sir, you and I, must have a touch.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Or two I hope Lovechange, before we part.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Are you so brisk Sir?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: You shall try that anon.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Draw then Sir, for I am ready.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Hold, hold, dear Lovechange, put up, we'l fight it out in another place.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: My noble Mistriss.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: My dear Lovechange the same, stole out purposely to meet thee, my Husband has found out our Intrigue, and I dare return no more, Ile tell you all the story at large, let's hastâ€” but whither?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I have taken a private Lodging on purpose to night in a friends house, whom I can trust, fear nothingâ€”

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: But thy inconstancy, Lovechange.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p:
Sooner thy soul may change it's goodness and generosity, or
any thing more impossible, come the Moons up, and we for our more security will go through the Park. Exeunt omnes

div.stage: Scene the Park, Enter Perigreen and Courtwell severally

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Here they say he's walking, I long to know the worst of my sad fate, 'tis strange he shou'd not know me, he's hereâ€”your Servant Sir.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Yours Sir, have you forgiven my Mornings Complement? how does your wound Sir?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Tis not troublesome.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Pray Sir, tell me, and tell me seriously, what mov'd you to this rage against me? how came you to be angry? you told me something of Camilla too, which Sir, has made me thoughtful ever since, are you indeed acquainted with that Lady?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Yes Sir, most intimately, there's nothing of her soul that's hid from me, she told me how she lov'd, and what false breath betraid her to that weakness.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Poor Camilla!

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Your pitty comes too late, for Sir she's dead, kil'd by your cruelty, which at once has rob'd the World, and me, of all we held most dear.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Since she's gone, Ile put this penance on my self; Ile marry nothing that is young, or beautiful.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: But can you talk of marrying any?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Why not Sir, whilst there be women and money to be had, and I suppose you will be of my mind too.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ha! Courtwell! come Sir, you and I must Tilt a little.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: How! for what? prithee leave fooling.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: For several Reasons, but first upon the Widdows score, you have debaucht her Sir.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: What dost mean Ned? I debauch the Widdow?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Yes, you Sir.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Thou'rt mad.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: No Sir, you have forgot the Lady you made love to, by the Duck-Pond side?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I had a Lady Sir, but she I thought had been thy Mistress.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: For that Ile kill thee too if possible.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: That were the juster quarrel of the two, but I have reason too, to fight with thee, who told the Widdow of my being there thinking to undermine me.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Come Sir, no argument, but this.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: D'ye hear Lovechange, pray don't fight, for then I must be forc'd to discover my self.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: This won't satisfie, stand by dear friend, my honour is engag'd, and I must fight,

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I wait you Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Dear Courtwell, don't fight, for if you dye, Ile wait on you to your Grave. weeps

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Whence comes this pretty softness? why for me?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Dost thou not know me yet? Methinks by my faint sigh, thou might'st discoverâ€” Thy once lov'd Camilla, at least this voice, might well enough inform thee. discovers her self

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: This is wondrous!

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Yes I do know thee, and am asham'd to tell thee that I do so.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: What the Devil, i'st a woman all this while?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I can forgive you, if you can be penitent, but on no other terms.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I wou'd not ask it any other way.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Don't let me ask thee that I am asham'd to sue to thee for, can you not guess what 'tis?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Marry thee, by all that's good Ile do't.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: This reformation pleases me, and ends our quarrels; come Sir I'me still your friend, if you need my assistance, I am at your service, if not, I have a little peice of transformation here too, that longs to be alone with me.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: A Woman this Ned?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Yes indeed, and the same you thought you had possest on the River-side.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Give me the honour of your hand Madam, and your forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p:
You have it Sir, and you pretty Sir, I hope we shall be better acquainted hereafter.
Exeunt Lovechange, and Mrs. Easy.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Come dear Camilla I will loose no time.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I'me overjoy'd at this return of Love!

May every moment the rich store improve.
Ex. Court. and Per.

div.stage: Scene Mr. Easy's house, Enter Sir Ralph in Womans Cloaths, to him Easy.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: One comfort I have yet, that my Wife is in my hands to handle how I please, Ile be reveng'd on her bones however, come impudence let me take you into examination, nay never hide your face, for you are past blushing, come to your Catechise, come.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: O Lord! what shall I do now? my Nuncle knows all, and I shall be hang'd. aside

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Hadst thou had fear before thy eyes, thou cou'dst not ha'been, to abomination, wicked?

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: I, I, 'tis plain, I do confess I am something wicked. cryes

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Are you so? where learnt you this ha? at Church?

sp.speaker: Sir Ral.
sp.p: No indeed Sir, I have not been at Church these many years.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy:
sp.p: Oh impudence! to confess this to me! was it for this, I took thee into my house? needy, and poor, and made Mistriss of all my family, my goods, my wealth, and now dost thou contrive to Cuckold me, to entertain a lewd Rascal to Whore thee, to mine, and thy eternal shame, what answer canst thou make?

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Hey toss! the old Man's mad, what the Devil does he mean now? aside

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: You must have your youngster with a Pox to you, I was the old Fool, the Cuckold, the Ass, to bear all, I, what say you in your vindication?

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: I am in good hope he does not take me, to be me, I were best to say nothing for fear he shou'd know me. aside

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Speak impudence, and tell truth, for it shall be thy last.

sp.speaker: Sir R.
sp.p: How! my last? I had as good speak and be hang'd, as have my throat cut silently, I don't like this same dying of any sort. aside

sp.speaker: Mr. E.
sp.p: What say you Mrs. Jilt, what say you for your self? not a word? Ile break silence then, take that, and thatâ€” and that, beats him.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Oh Plague of your chastising, hold, hold!

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Oh are you plyant, are you Mistriss?

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Yes Sir as plyant as you shall be immediately.

div.stage: Gets a Battoon and beats Easy.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Murther, murther, dost thou add this to thy other wickedness? of chastising thy own natural Husband.

sp.speaker: Sir R.
sp.p: You lye Sir, you lye, I am none of your Wife, I defie thee, renounce me quickly, or Ile beat thee into nothing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Renounce thee? yes I do renounce thee, for thou art a most notorious Whore, and I scorn thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: I will beat thee, till thou deny that too, come Sir about, about, exercise your musty part, come Sir. beats him agen.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Murther, murther! no help? shall I be kill'd like Acteon with my own Bitch, ha?

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Nay, now I shall be betraid.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Dear Madam! why so cruel! let me interpose?

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Who art thou.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: One Sir, related to you now, I am Amorous and thy Kinsman.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: How! oh undone! undone!

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Not so Sir, Grace will give me a better Character, and you must be contented for we are married Sir.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Yes indeed Sir, we are married, and beg your good liking of it.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Amorous alive! and married to Grace? nay then 'tis no time to dissemble.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Oh miserable man! Grace married to thee? how many misfortunes arrive on the neck one of another to make me unhappy, my Wife a Whore, and my Neece married, oh, oh, ho.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Nay Sir, Ile keep you company, for I am the miserabler man of the two.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Why who are you?

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Wou'd I had a Wife, to have been a Whore too for me, wou'd I had been the biggest Cuckold in London, so I had had Grace and all her money.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Worse, and worse! what art thou?

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: What am I? what shou'd I be? a man as thou art, I amâ€”

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Sir Ralph Spatter?

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Yes, that I am, i'me sure you have us'd me scurvily.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: This not my Wife?

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: No, not your wife Sir, I wou'd I were any thing but Sir Ralph, any thing but damnable cheating, cozening woman.

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: I always told you Sir Ralph, that I wou'd never marry any but Mr. Amorous:

sp.speaker: Sir R.
sp.p: I thought I had made him sure, why Sir if it were not you that was dead? who was it I kill'd?

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p:
Sir, I will shew you presently.
Goes out, and brings in Jo in Amorous's Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: How! my own man! Io! nay if I had thought t'had been but him that I kill'd, I had never took this disguise.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Why Sir, had I been kill'd, you wou'd as soon have hang'd for't, as for Mr. Amorous.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Why, thou wer't not dead then?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: No indeed Sir, which was no fault of yours, but of my own natural ability, for you laid it on, without mercy.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter, why did not you speak then?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Because you wou'd not let me, nor hear me when I did, but I thank my stars you are serv'd in your kind.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: And didst thou know of the going away of these two Lovers?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Yes Sir, but durst not resist them, I wou'd have pursu'd 'em, had you given me leave to speak.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: How got you loose and be hang'd, when the Steed was stoln?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: By great good Fortune, Mrs. Peg coming to look for Mr. Amorous his dead body as you directed, found me, and untying me, saw 'twas I, and conjur'd me in return to that good office, not to come into your presence, till I knew Mr. Amorous, and Mrs. Grace, were married.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: How! Rogues amongst our selves? my own servant turn upon me, well Jo, well, Ile be even with thee for this, however I thrive.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Well, since I cannot strive against fate, and that I think I am not long liv'd, I will say Heavens bless you together; and you Sir Ralph, I only desire to know how you came in my Wives Night-cloaths, 'twas not long since you past out of my house, boasting your love for my Wife, and telling meâ€”

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Who I Sir, no, no, 'twas not I, alas I flew hither by Peg's advice for refuge, but I find 'twas only a trick to abuse me with, and to help your Wife to make an escape.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p:
Escape! Why, is my Wife gone? nay then by this time she has acted, what before was but design'd, and by this time I am a most formidable monster, however I am arriv'd to this knowledge,
that nothing can oppose a womans will. But Ile be divorc'd from her, and let her see, what her new Gallant will do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: What's here to do, more mischief? nay, nay, never bow to me, I imagine what 'tis you wou'd say; pardon me Sir for the freedom I have taken in chusing a Wife without your approbation, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: You are in the right Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Am I so Sir? A Pox take ye all, may you be Cuckolds as great as I am! and have the consolation to know it, as well as I do, with all my heart, I say, with all my heart, de' ye hear?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Sir, I am come, not out of kindness to you, but revenge, to let you knowâ€”

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: That I am a Cuckold, a contented yeilding Cuckold, yes spare your pains, I know't, I know't, Mistriss d'ye hear, I know't, and am contented, and what have you to say to this, ha?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I am glad you know your misery as well as I do mine.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Thine? I wish no better companion, much good may it do you, d'ye hear? very much good, oh it lightens my heart!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I have a Husband Sir â€”

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Yes, and I have a Wifeâ€” Confound herâ€”

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: And do you know my Husband is the man that Cuckolds you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: How! thy Husband! still better, and better! I desire no greater Plague shou'd befall you, then to feel what I doe.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: You are very uncharitable, but Sir I find my heart much at ease, and since this common Calamity has befal'n me, I am resolv'd to make the best on't, I have put off my Husband, and intend to entertain a Gallant.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Faith Madam i'me sorry I cannot serve you, for i'me newly entring upon that dangerous Sea, where you have been too lately ship-wrack't.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Why Mr. Courtwell, you are not married?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Yes indeed am I.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Faith Madam, i'de 'en think of Mr. Perigreen, he's very pretty, and very young.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Say'st thou so Clare? to thy hearts breaking, behold, that pretty young Gentleman is become a Lady, and my Wife, Clare.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Is he? well there's no trust in humane things! well the Town's wide, and many distressed Gamesters will be glad upon a loosing hand, to be kind.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Nay if Mr. Courtwell be gone, I will never think of his Sex more, but thus kind Ile be to Lovechange, to beg of you Mr. Easy, to resign your Wife to him, being much fitter to be his Mistress.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: I do renounce her, let her do what she will, Ile have a Mistriss too, and will be young agen, what say you Betty?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Sir, I never lik't an old man much, especially having been so lately a Lady to a young Knight.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: Sure Jo, Ile take thy counsel, 'twere simple to go home and be laught at, as all the Country will do, if I return without a wife.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Besides Sir, you will have your thousand pounds agen.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: I, I, I consider'd that too man! come Mrs. Betty if you think fit, Ile 'en take you instead of Mrs. Grace, ungrateful Grace. â€”

sp.speaker: Grace.
sp.p: Indeed Sir Ralph, she'l make a good wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Ralph.
sp.p: She's the worse for thy recommendations, but however she shall take the wall of her Mistriss.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Well said Sir Ralph, I like your resolution, I will be young agen, and gay, and I will like every Extravagance, here take Betty, and we'l send for the musick; I will dance, and forget all sorrow, oh that my Wife, my kind, my handsome young Wife, were here now, I wou'd give her to Lovechange, yes heartily, and wish 'em joy together, come, some musick there, I will not ask you Amorous, what settlement my Neece has, for I believe she deserves none, they will be all alike, all turnâ€” 'tis no matter whatâ€” nor you Nephew, I will not ask what Fortune your Wife has, for be she rich, or be she poor, she will prove an errantâ€” Much good may't do you Sir, I am young agen, and will live as lewdly as the best of you, come fall to dancing, be merry, very merry, whilst you may, for sorrow will come fast enough Ile warrant ye, come, come, to Frisking, to Frisking. They Dance.

div.stage: Enter Lovechange and Mrs. Easy in Masquerade.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: By your leave Sirâ€”

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: Gentlemen y'are welcome, very welcome.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: I doubt you wou'd recall that word, if you knew who we were.

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: You are mistaken Sir, I care not if you be Lovechange, and my quondam Wife, d'ye hear, you are still welcome.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Say you so Sir, then have at ye. discovers

sp.speaker: Mr. Easy.
sp.p: So, I like this well, I am pleas'd, wondrous pleas'd, here Sir, instead of affronting you, I will present you, come Sir, never hang back, I know you well, hereâ€” liveâ€” and lyeâ€” and be hang'd â€” together if you please, with all my heart d'ye hear? I am not angry, no the business is done, I am a Cuckold that's not my fault, but I will not be a Fool, and so, much good may it do you kindly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Easy.
sp.p: Well Sir, I thank you, 'tis no disgrace to be a Mistriss as the World goes.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Faith Sir, in this gift, you have been so generous, and obliging, that I have nothing to return but my Wife, by my troth Sir, try her, your Nephew has found her brisk and active, she's a good soul, she made an excellent Wife for the time, perhaps she may repair by you, the loss she has sustaind by me.

sp.speaker: Easy.
sp.l: But while these gods Almighty, Guinneys reign, shews a purse
The needy Miss, though chast, can scarce contain
Religion, and her Hosts of Vertues, prove
Too yeilding, to resist such pow'r of Love.
Jove never rain'd in Gold, but you found Laps,
Without respect to after Thunder-claps:
The loose Gallant grown poor, must yeild, and then
Hey for old Wine, old Treasures, and old Men.

div.head: The Epilogue.
div.l: WHat has our Poet done you look so big,
Has he not treated you with brisk Intrigue?
Some with dull Morals, wou'd affront the Age,
And make a Conventicle of the Stage.
Shou'd he, but treat you with such things as those be:
Damn the sententious Fopâ€” comeâ€” let's to Mosely.
Wou'd ye recall some stories of your own,
What on this Tuft, what on that Bank was done,
Our Play perhaps uncensur'd might have gone.
You Rogue cryes one, behold on yonder side,
I joy to name it; I, and Phillis dy'd:
Another with fierce Indignation rap't,
Cryes, Damn her for a Whore there were I Clap't:
Another year, whoever lives, and sees,
I fear you'l rub the Rind off from the Trees.
Yet for all this, nothing can relish well,
Vnless we huff the gods, and hector Hell:
With Wit, and Women, you deal much at one,
First you debauch, and then you cry 'um down.
